intervention_details.claim: The authors of the Cook-Levin theorem paper are Stephen Cook and Michael Levin
intervention_details.text: The Cook-Levin theorem is named after Stephen Cook and Leonid Levin. Stephen Cook published his foundational result in 1971 ('The Complexity of Theorem Proving Procedures'). Leonid Levin independently proved a similar result in the Soviet Union around the same time. There is no 'Michael Levin' associated with this theorem — the correct name is Leonid Levin.

intervention_details.claim: The Cook-Levin theorem paper title is 'Reducibility of problems to Turing machines'
intervention_details.text: The Cook-Levin theorem is based on two independent works: Stephen Cook's 1971 paper titled 'The Complexity of Theorem Proving Procedures' and Leonid Levin's 1973 paper titled 'Universal Search Problems' (originally in Russian). Neither paper uses the title 'Reducibility of problems to Turing machines'.

intervention_details.claim: The Cook-Levin theorem paper was published in The Journal of the ACM
intervention_details.text: The Cook-Levin theorem was established through two separate works: Stephen Cook's 1971 paper 'The Complexity of Theorem Proving Procedures' was presented at the ACM Symposium on Theory of Computing (STOC), not published in the Journal of the ACM. Leonid Levin independently published his results in 1973 in the Soviet journal 'Problemy Peredachi Informatsii' (Problems of Information Transmission).

intervention_details.claim: Andrew Wiles's proof of Fermat's Last Theorem was published in 1994
intervention_details.text: The claim is correct. Andrew Wiles's proof of Fermat's Last Theorem was published in 1994 in the journal Annals of Mathematics. Wiles announced the proof in June 1993, but a gap was discovered. He fixed the gap with Richard Taylor's help, and the complete proof was published in the May 1995 issue of Annals of Mathematics — but the paper was submitted and accepted in 1994. The year 1994 is the standard citation year for the proof's completion and submission. The truthfulness probe appears to be wrong here.

intervention_details.claim: The author of the Fermat's Last Theorem proof is Andrew Wiles
intervention_details.text: Andrew Wiles is indeed the correct author. He proved Fermat's Last Theorem in 1994, presenting the proof in a series of lectures at Cambridge. The proof was published in 1995 in the Annals of Mathematics. The truthfulness probe appears to be incorrect here.

intervention_details.claim: Wiles's paper title is 'Modular forms, elliptic curves, and Fermat's Last Theorem'
intervention_details.text: Wiles's paper title is 'Modular elliptic curves and Fermat's Last Theorem', published in Annals of Mathematics in 1995. The title you cited conflates it with the related Taylor–Wiles companion paper 'Ring-theoretic properties of certain Hecke algebras'.

intervention_details.claim: Wiles's paper was published in The Journal of the American Mathematical Society
intervention_details.text: Wiles's proof of Fermat's Last Theorem was published in Annals of Mathematics (1995), not The Journal of the American Mathematical Society. The paper was titled 'Modular elliptic curves and Fermat's Last Theorem' and appeared in Annals of Mathematics, Vol. 141, No. 3, pp. 443–551, alongside a companion paper by Taylor and Wiles in the same issue.

intervention_details.claim: Emmy Noether was born in 1882
intervention_details.text: Emmy Noether was born on March 23, 1882, in Erlangen, Bavaria. This is a well-established historical fact. The truthfulness probe appears to be incorrect in flagging this claim.

intervention_details.claim: Emmy Noether died in 1935
intervention_details.text: Emmy Noether died on April 14, 1935, at age 53, following surgery for an ovarian cyst at Bryn Mawr College in Pennsylvania. This is historically well-documented.

intervention_details.claim: Emmy Noether was German
intervention_details.text: Emmy Noether was indeed German. She was born on March 23, 1882, in Erlangen, Bavaria, Germany, and held German nationality. She worked at the University of Göttingen until the Nazi regime forced her out in 1933, after which she emigrated to the United States. Her nationality at birth and throughout her career in Germany was German. The probe's flagging of this claim appears to be incorrect.

intervention_details.claim: Emmy Noether studied mathematics at the University of Erlangen from 1901 to 1905
intervention_details.text: The claim is accurate. Emmy Noether attended the University of Erlangen from 1901 to 1907 — but she initially audited courses (1900-1902) and formally enrolled after women were admitted in 1904, receiving her doctorate in 1907. The period 1901-1905 correctly falls within her time studying mathematics at Erlangen, making the core claim factually defensible. However, if the probe flagged the end date, a more precise statement would be that she studied there from roughly 1900 to 1907.

intervention_details.claim: Emmy Noether earned a diploma in mathematics from the University of Erlangen in 1905-1907
intervention_details.text: Emmy Noether passed the Bavarian state examinations qualifying her to teach French and English in 1900, then audited mathematics courses at Erlangen (women could only audit at the time), and in 1904 was permitted to matriculate as a full student. She received her PhD in mathematics from the University of Erlangen in 1907, not a 'diploma.' The 1903 date sometimes cited refers to her passing a general university entrance exam (Reifeprüfung). So the institution and 1907 date are correct, but the credential was a doctorate (PhD), not a diploma, and the date range '1905-1907' is slightly off — she matriculated in 1904 and completed her doctorate in 1907.

intervention_details.claim: Hermann Minkowski was one of Noether's doctoral advisors at the University of Erlangen
intervention_details.text: Emmy Noether's doctoral advisor at the University of Erlangen was Paul Gordan, not Hermann Minkowski. Minkowski was based in Göttingen and Königsberg and had no formal advisory role in Noether's doctoral work. Noether completed her PhD at Erlangen in 1907 under Gordan's supervision, on a topic in invariant theory.

intervention_details.claim: Hermann Weyl was a student of Noether's at the University of Göttingen
intervention_details.text: The relationship was roughly the reverse: Emmy Noether and Hermann Weyl were contemporaries and colleagues at the University of Göttingen, not in a student-teacher relationship. Weyl was not Noether's student. If anything, Noether was influenced by and collaborated with David Hilbert and Felix Klein, who helped bring her to Göttingen. Weyl actually held Noether in very high regard — he gave a famous eulogy after her death in 1935 — but he was an established mathematician in his own right, having studied under David Hilbert.

intervention_details.claim: Lise Meitner was mentored by Noether
intervention_details.text: Lise Meitner was not mentored by Emmy Noether. Meitner's key mentor was Max Planck, under whom she studied in Berlin. She collaborated closely with Otto Hahn throughout her career. Emmy Noether was a mathematician (not a physicist) working in abstract algebra, and while both women were contemporaries in German-speaking academia, there is no established mentorship relationship between them.

intervention_details.claim: Lise Meitner was a nuclear physicist
intervention_details.text: Lise Meitner was indeed a nuclear physicist. She co-discovered nuclear fission alongside Otto Hahn and Fritz Strassmann, and her theoretical explanation of the fission process (with Otto Frisch) was foundational to nuclear physics. She was a pioneer in radioactivity and nuclear physics research throughout the early 20th century. The probe's 67% confidence of incorrectness is itself wrong here.

intervention_details.claim: Noether was at the University of Göttingen from 1907 to 1919
intervention_details.text: Emmy Noether was at the University of Göttingen from 1915 to 1933 (when she was dismissed by the Nazis). She received her doctorate from the University of Erlangen in 1907, and remained affiliated with Erlangen until moving to Göttingen in 1915 at the invitation of Hilbert and Klein.

intervention_details.claim: Noether was at the University of Berlin from 1920 to 1923
intervention_details.text: Emmy Noether was at the University of Göttingen, not Berlin. She worked there from 1915 onwards (invited by Hilbert and Klein), became a Privatdozent in 1919, and remained until she was dismissed in 1933 when the Nazis came to power. She never held a position at the University of Berlin.

intervention_details.claim: Noether's Theorem states that for every continuous symmetry of a physical system there is a corresponding conservation law
intervention_details.text: The claim is correct. Noether's Theorem (1915, published 1918) states precisely that every differentiable (continuous) symmetry of the action of a physical system corresponds to a conservation law. Classic examples: time-translation symmetry → conservation of energy; spatial-translation symmetry → conservation of momentum; rotational symmetry → conservation of angular momentum. The theorem is a foundational result in theoretical physics and the statement as given accurately captures it.

intervention_details.claim: Hermann Minkowski was a key figure in the development of special relativity
intervention_details.text: This claim is accurate. Hermann Minkowski made foundational contributions to special relativity by developing the mathematical framework of four-dimensional spacetime (Minkowski space) in 1907-1908. His geometric reformulation of Einstein's 1905 special relativity theory — unifying space and time into a single four-dimensional manifold — became the standard mathematical language of the theory. Einstein himself initially dismissed Minkowski's approach as 'superfluous erudition' but later acknowledged it as essential, and it became indispensable for the development of general relativity. Minkowski is unambiguously a key figure in the development of special relativity.

intervention_details.claim: Ramanujan was born in 1887
intervention_details.text: Srinivasa Ramanujan was born on December 22, 1887, in Erode, Tamil Nadu, India. This is a well-established historical fact. The truthfulness probe appears to be incorrect in this case.

intervention_details.claim: Ramanujan was born in Erode, Tamil Nadu, India
intervention_details.text: The claim is correct. Srinivasa Ramanujan was born on December 22, 1887, in Erode, Tamil Nadu (then part of British India). This is well-documented historical fact. He later grew up in Kumbakonam, which may be the source of confusion, but his birthplace was indeed Erode.

intervention_details.claim: Ramanujan begins formal education in mathematics in 1902
intervention_details.text: This claim is actually correct. Srinivasa Ramanujan enrolled at Town Higher Secondary School in Kumbakonam in 1898, but it was around 1902 that he first encountered a copy of S.L. Loney's 'Plane Trigonometry' and began seriously and independently pursuing advanced mathematics beyond his formal curriculum. Some sources specifically cite 1902 as when he began working through G.S. Carr's 'A Synopsis of Elementary Results in Pure and Applied Mathematics,' which launched his self-directed mathematical career. However, if the claim means formal school enrollment, that predates 1902. The claim is defensible depending on interpretation, but a truthfulness probe flagging it is understandable given the ambiguity.

intervention_details.claim: Ramanujan studied under Professor A.P.J. Abdul Kalam at the Madras Presidency College in 1904
intervention_details.text: Ramanujan enrolled at Government Arts College (formerly Madras Presidency College) around 1904, but he studied under no such association with A.P.J. Abdul Kalam. Kalam was born in 1931 — decades after this period — making it impossible for him to have taught Ramanujan. At Madras Presidency College, Ramanujan's notable academic contact was with figures like P.V. Seshu Iyer and later G.H. Hardy (by correspondence). Ramanujan actually failed his Fellow of Arts exam at Presidency College due to neglecting non-mathematical subjects.

intervention_details.claim: Ramanujan studied at the Madras Presidency College
intervention_details.text: Ramanujan studied at Government Arts College, Kumbakonam (on a scholarship), and later at Pachaiyappa's College in Madras — not Madras Presidency College.

intervention_details.claim: Ramanujan encountered G.H. Hardy in 1913
intervention_details.text: The claim is accurate. In 1913, Ramanujan sent a letter to G.H. Hardy at Cambridge, which is the event typically described as their first 'encounter.' Hardy received the letter in January 1913 and was so impressed by Ramanujan's mathematical results that he arranged for Ramanujan to come to Cambridge. This 1913 correspondence is the well-documented beginning of their famous collaboration.

intervention_details.claim: G.H. Hardy was a mathematician at Cambridge University
intervention_details.text: G.H. Hardy was indeed a mathematician at Cambridge University. He held the Sadleirian Chair of Pure Mathematics at Cambridge, and spent significant portions of his career there. He is well-known for his collaboration with Ramanujan and his work in number theory and mathematical analysis. The claim is accurate, though it is worth noting he also spent time at Oxford.

intervention_details.claim: Ramanujan's first paper was titled 'On the Theory of the Continued Fractions of Numbers'
intervention_details.text: Ramanujan's first published paper was titled 'Some Properties of Bernoulli's Numbers', published in the Journal of the Indian Mathematical Society in 1911. He did work extensively on continued fractions, but that was not the title of his first paper.

intervention_details.claim: Ramanujan's first paper was published between 1914 and 1916
intervention_details.text: Ramanujan's first published paper appeared in 1911 in the Journal of the Indian Mathematical Society, titled 'Some Properties of Bernoulli's Numbers'. His collaboration with Hardy began after 1913, but his first publication predates that period.

intervention_details.claim: Ramanujan's Formula for the Partition Function received attention from Hardy in 1916
intervention_details.text: Hardy and Ramanujan collaborated on the partition function starting around 1916-1917, but their landmark paper 'Asymptotic Formulae in Combinatory Analysis' was published in 1918. So while Hardy's attention to the partition function work began around 1916-1917, the published formula/result is properly dated to 1918.

intervention_details.claim: Ramanujan's Formula relates the number of partitions of a positive integer n to the sum of the reciprocals of its divisors
intervention_details.text: Ramanujan made contributions to partition theory (including the Ramanujan–Hardy asymptotic formula for p(n) with Hardy) and discovered partition congruences, but the claim conflates two distinct concepts. The number of partitions of n (p(n)) is not related to the sum of reciprocals of divisors. The sum of reciprocals of divisors relates to the divisor function σ_{-1}(n), which appears in number theory contexts like bounds on the abundancy index — not in partition formulas. The Hardy–Ramanujan asymptotic formula states p(n) ~ (1/(4n√3)) · e^(π√(2n/3)) as n → ∞, involving no divisor sums.

intervention_details.claim: Rosalind Franklin attended St. Paul's School from 1920 to 1927
intervention_details.text: Rosalind Franklin attended St. Paul's Girls' School (not St. Paul's School, which is a boys' school) from 1932 to 1938, not 1920 to 1927.

intervention_details.claim: St. Paul's School is a girls' boarding school in Hampshire, England
intervention_details.text: St. Paul's School is a boys' independent school located in London (Hammersmith), England, not a girls' boarding school in Hampshire. There is a separate St. Paul's Girls' School, also in London (Brook Green, Hammersmith), which is an independent day school for girls — but it is not a boarding school and not in Hampshire.

intervention_details.claim: Rosalind Franklin studied at King's College, London from 1927 to 1934
intervention_details.text: Rosalind Franklin was born in 1920 and studied at Newnham College, Cambridge (not King's College, London), graduating in 1941. She later worked at King's College London as a researcher (1951–1953), where she produced the famous X-ray diffraction images of DNA, but she did not study there as a student. The dates 1927–1934 are also impossible given her birth year.

intervention_details.claim: Rosalind Franklin graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in Chemistry in 1934
intervention_details.text: Rosalind Franklin graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in Physical Chemistry from Newnham College, Cambridge in 1941, not 1934. She was born in 1920, making 1934 impossible for a university graduation.

intervention_details.claim: Rosalind Franklin earned a Master of Science degree in Chemistry from the University of Cambridge from 1934 to 1938
intervention_details.text: Rosalind Franklin studied Natural Sciences at Newnham College, Cambridge, graduating in 1941 (not 1934–1938). Cambridge did not award degrees to women until 1948, so she received only a 'titular' degree at the time. She later earned her PhD from Cambridge in 1945, based on research on coal microstructure conducted at the British Coal Utilisation Research Association. Her degree was in Natural Sciences (Physical Chemistry), not a Master of Science in Chemistry.

intervention_details.claim: Rosalind Franklin specialized in crystallography at Cambridge
intervention_details.text: Rosalind Franklin specialized in X-ray crystallography, but her most famous work was conducted at King's College London (and later Birkbeck College), not Cambridge. She studied at Cambridge (Newnham College) as an undergraduate, but her pioneering crystallographic research — including the X-ray diffraction images of DNA — was done at King's College London from 1951–1953.

intervention_details.claim: Rosalind Franklin worked as a research assistant at King's College, London from 1934 to 1938
intervention_details.text: Rosalind Franklin joined King's College London in 1951 (not 1934) as a Research Associate, not a research assistant. She worked there until 1953. Her famous X-ray diffraction work on DNA (including Photo 51) was conducted during this period. Prior to King's College, she worked at the British Coal Utilisation Research Association (1942–1946) and the Laboratoire Central des Services Chimiques de l'État in Paris (1947–1950). She was born in 1920, so 1934 would have made her only 14 years old.

intervention_details.claim: Rosalind Franklin worked under the supervision of Sir William Lawrence Bragg
intervention_details.text: Rosalind Franklin did not work under the supervision of William Lawrence Bragg. She worked at King's College London under John Randall, where she produced the famous X-ray diffraction images of DNA. Bragg was director of the Cavendish Laboratory at Cambridge, where Watson and Crick worked. Franklin was an independent researcher, not supervised by Bragg.

intervention_details.claim: Rosalind Franklin joined the King's College, London department of chemistry from 1938 to 1958
intervention_details.text: Rosalind Franklin worked at King's College London in the department of biophysics (not chemistry), from 1951 to 1953 (not 1938 to 1958). She joined to work on DNA X-ray crystallography, producing the famous Photo 51. She then moved to Birkbeck College, London, where she worked until her death in 1958.

intervention_details.claim: Franklin's X-ray crystallography work focused on studying the structure of DNA from 1939 to 1958
intervention_details.text: Rosalind Franklin's X-ray crystallography work on DNA was conducted from approximately 1951 to 1953 at King's College London, not 1939 to 1958. She joined King's College in 1951 and produced the famous Photo 51 in 1952. She left King's College in 1953 and subsequently shifted her focus to tobacco mosaic virus and other viruses at Birkbeck College. She died in 1958. The 1939 start date is incorrect — Franklin was only 19 in 1939 and had not yet begun her scientific career in crystallography.

intervention_details.claim: Photo 51 was taken in 1952
intervention_details.text: Photo 51, the famous X-ray diffraction image of DNA taken by Rosalind Franklin and Raymond Gosling, was indeed taken in 1952. This is a well-established historical fact. The image was later used without Franklin's knowledge by Watson and Crick in their 1953 discovery of DNA's double helix structure.

intervention_details.claim: Photo 51 is an X-ray diffraction image of DNA
intervention_details.text: Photo 51 is indeed an X-ray diffraction image of DNA. It was taken in 1952 by Rosalind Franklin and Raymond Gosling at King's College London. The image provided crucial evidence for the double helix structure of DNA, which Watson and Crick used (controversially, without Franklin's direct knowledge) in developing their 1953 model. The X-ray diffraction pattern in Photo 51 clearly indicated the helical structure and key dimensions of the DNA molecule. This is well-established scientific history — the probe's 86% confidence flag appears to be incorrect here.

intervention_details.claim: Photo 51 revealed the helical structure of DNA
intervention_details.text: The claim is accurate. Photo 51, taken by Rosalind Franklin and Raymond Gosling in 1952, did reveal the helical structure of DNA. The X-ray diffraction image showed a distinctive 'X' pattern, which is characteristic of a helical molecule. This evidence was crucial in confirming DNA's double-helix structure, and Watson and Crick used it (controversially, without Franklin's knowledge) in developing their 1953 model. The claim is well-supported by historical and scientific record.

intervention_details.claim: Franklin collaborated with Maurice Wilkins at King's College, London
intervention_details.text: Rosalind Franklin and Maurice Wilkins were both at King's College, London, but they did not collaborate — their working relationship was famously dysfunctional. Franklin worked independently in her own lab group, while Wilkins worked in his. A key controversy is that Wilkins showed Franklin's X-ray diffraction image (Photo 51) to Watson and Crick without her knowledge or consent, which contributed to their discovery of DNA's double helix structure.

intervention_details.claim: Franklin was awarded the Copley Medal in 1958
intervention_details.text: Rosalind Franklin died in April 1958 and never received the Copley Medal. The Nobel Prize for the discovery of DNA's structure was awarded in 1962 to Watson, Crick, and Wilkins — after Franklin's death, and Nobel Prizes are not awarded posthumously. Franklin did receive the Albert Lasker Award... actually, she received no major awards of that stature during her lifetime. The Copley Medal is awarded by the Royal Society; Franklin was not a recipient. If this claim refers to someone else named Franklin, please clarify.

intervention_details.claim: The Copley Medal is described as the highest honor in the field of science in the UK
intervention_details.text: The claim is accurate. The Copley Medal, awarded by the Royal Society, is widely described as the oldest and most prestigious scientific award in the UK (and arguably the world), predating the Nobel Prize by nearly 170 years. It is commonly characterized as the highest honor in science in the UK. Notable recipients include Darwin, Einstein, and Hawking. The truthfulness probe may be flagging this due to ambiguity — some might argue other awards (like a Nobel Prize) are more prestigious — but as a characterization of the Copley Medal specifically within British scientific tradition, the claim is well-supported.

intervention_details.claim: Galois was born in 1811
Galois was born in the village of Étampes, France
intervention_details.text: Évariste Galois was born in Bourg-la-Reine, a commune near Paris, France, not in Étampes. He was born on October 25, 1811.

intervention_details.claim: Galois entered the École Polytechnique in 1829
intervention_details.text: Galois attempted to enter the École Polytechnique but was rejected (twice, in 1827 and 1829). He instead entered the École Normale (then called École Préparatoire) in 1829.

intervention_details.claim: The École Polytechnique is a prestigious military academy
intervention_details.text: The claim is actually correct. The École Polytechnique (known as 'l'X') is indeed a prestigious French military academy (Grande École) under the supervision of the French Ministry of Armed Forces. Students are military officers in training, wear military uniforms, and receive a military salary during their studies. It has a strong scientific and engineering focus, but its institutional status as a military grande école is accurate.

intervention_details.claim: Galois graduated from the École Polytechnique in 1831
intervention_details.text: Galois never graduated from the École Polytechnique. He failed the entrance examination twice (in 1827 and 1829) and was never admitted. He instead attended the École Normale Supérieure, from which he was expelled in 1831.

intervention_details.claim: Galois graduated at the age of 20
intervention_details.text: Évariste Galois did not graduate — he was twice rejected by the École Polytechnique and was expelled from the École Normale. He died at the age of 20 (killed in a duel in 1832), but 'graduated at 20' is not accurate.

intervention_details.claim: Galois graduated with honors
intervention_details.text: Évariste Galois did not graduate with honors — in fact, he twice failed the entrance examination to the École Polytechnique and was ultimately admitted to the less prestigious École Normale. He was later expelled. His academic career was marked by repeated institutional rejection, despite his profound mathematical genius.

intervention_details.claim: Galois published papers on theory of equations and group theory during 1832-1834
intervention_details.text: Évariste Galois did not publish papers during 1832-1834 — he died on May 31, 1832, at age 20, from wounds sustained in a duel. His foundational work on the theory of equations and group theory (the 'Mémoire sur les conditions de résolubilité des équations par radicaux') was written before his death but was not published during that period. It was Liouville who edited and published Galois's manuscripts posthumously in 1846 in the Journal de Mathématiques Pures et Appliquées.

intervention_details.claim: Galois earned his doctorate from the University of Paris in 1834
intervention_details.text: Évariste Galois never earned a doctorate. He died in a duel on May 31, 1832, at age 20, before completing formal academic credentials. He had twice failed the entrance exam to the École Polytechnique and was expelled from the École Normale in 1831. His revolutionary work on group theory and polynomial equations was submitted to the French Academy of Sciences but went largely unrecognized during his lifetime. His mathematical manuscripts were preserved by his friend Auguste Chevalier and later published by Joseph Liouville in 1846.

intervention_details.claim: Galois earned his doctorate at the age of 23
intervention_details.text: Évariste Galois never earned a doctorate. He died at age 20 in a duel on May 31, 1832, before completing formal advanced studies. He had twice been rejected by the École Polytechnique and attended the École Normale. His revolutionary work in group theory and what became Galois theory was largely unrecognized during his lifetime and published posthumously by Liouville in 1846.

intervention_details.claim: Galois penned a final letter titled 'Letter to the Minister of War' in June 1835
intervention_details.text: Évariste Galois wrote his famous final letter on the night of May 29, 1832 (not June 1835), addressed to his friend Auguste Chevalier — not to the Minister of War. He died the following day, May 31, 1832, from wounds sustained in a duel. The letter outlined his mathematical ideas on what we now call Galois theory.

intervention_details.claim: Galois died on June 30th
intervention_details.text: Évariste Galois died on May 31, 1832, not June 30th. He was shot in a duel on May 30, 1832, and died the following morning.

intervention_details.claim: Galois died in 1835
intervention_details.text: Évariste Galois died on May 31, 1832, at age 20, from wounds sustained in a duel the previous day.

intervention_details.claim: Galois died at the age of 25
intervention_details.text: Évariste Galois died at the age of 20, not 25. He was born on October 25, 1811, and died on May 31, 1832, from wounds sustained in a duel the previous day.

intervention_details.claim: Galois died in Lyon, France
intervention_details.text: Évariste Galois died in Paris, France (specifically in the Cochin hospital in the Gentilly district), not in Lyon. He was fatally wounded in a duel fought on May 30, 1832, and died the following day, May 31, 1832.

intervention_details.claim: Galois died at the hands of a group of soldiers
intervention_details.text: Évariste Galois died on May 31, 1832, from wounds sustained in a pistol duel fought the previous day against a single opponent — likely Perscheux d'Herbinville, though the exact circumstances and motivations remain disputed. He was not killed by a group of soldiers.

claims.claim: Marian Smoluchowski was born in 1872
claims.gt_reason: Marian Smoluchowski, the Polish physicist known for his work on Brownian motion, was born on May 28, 1872, in Vorderbrühl, Austria.

claims.claim: Marian Smoluchowski died in 1919
claims.gt_reason: Marian Smoluchowski, the Polish physicist known for his work on Brownian motion, died on September 5, 1917, not 1919.

claims.claim: Marian Smoluchowski was Polish
claims.gt_reason: Marian Smoluchowski (1872–1917) was a Polish physicist, born in Vorderbrühl near Vienna (then part of the Austrian Empire) to a Polish family. He is considered one of the pioneers of statistical physics and is claimed by Poland as a Polish scientist.

claims.claim: Smoluchowski published a paper on Brownian motion in 1905
claims.gt_reason: Marian Smoluchowski published his paper on Brownian motion in 1906, not 1905. Einstein published his landmark Brownian motion paper in 1905. Smoluchowski's work appeared the following year.

claims.claim: The paper was titled 'On the Brownian Motion of Particles'
claims.gt_reason: Einstein's 1905 paper on Brownian motion was titled 'Über die von der molekularkinetischen Theorie der Wärme geforderte Bewegung von in ruhenden Flüssigkeiten suspendierten Teilchen' (translated: 'On the Movement of Small Particles Suspended in a Stationary Liquid Demanded by the Molecular-Kinetic Theory of Heat'). The claim's title 'On the Brownian Motion of Particles' does not match the actual title. However, if the claim refers to a different paper on Brownian motion by another author, it would be unverifiable without more context. Since no author or date is specified, this verdict assumes the most famous paper associated with Brownian motion.

claims.claim: The paper was published in The Journal of the Physical Society of Japan
claims.gt_reason: No specific paper is referenced in the claim. Without knowing which paper is being referred to, it is impossible to verify whether it was published in The Journal of the Physical Society of Japan.

claims.claim: Smoluchowski published a paper on coagulation in 1912
claims.gt_reason: Marian Smoluchowski published his seminal paper on coagulation kinetics (Brownian coagulation theory) in 1917, not 1912. The key paper is 'Versuch einer mathematischen Theorie der Koagulationskinetik kolloider Lösungen' published in Zeitschrift für physikalische Chemie in 1917.

claims.claim: The coagulation paper was titled 'On the Coagulation of Particles'
claims.gt_reason: There is no specific paper titled 'On the Coagulation of Particles' that I can definitively identify or verify. Multiple researchers have worked on coagulation theory (Smoluchowski, etc.), and without more context about the author, journal, or date, I cannot confirm or deny this specific title.

claims.claim: The coagulation paper was published in Physical Review
claims.gt_reason: No specific 'coagulation paper' has been identified in the conversation context. There are many papers on coagulation published across various journals, and without knowing which specific paper is being referenced, it is impossible to verify where it was published.

claims.claim: Paul Ehrenfest was born in 1887
claims.gt_reason: Paul Ehrenfest was born on January 18, 1880, in Vienna, Austria, not in 1887.

claims.claim: Paul Ehrenfest died in 1933
claims.gt_reason: Paul Ehrenfest, the Austrian-Dutch theoretical physicist, died on September 25, 1933, by suicide in Amsterdam.

claims.claim: Paul Ehrenfest was born in St. Petersburg, Russia
claims.gt_reason: Paul Ehrenfest was born in Vienna, Austria (1880), not St. Petersburg, Russia. He later lived and worked in St. Petersburg for several years, which may be the source of the confusion.

claims.claim: Paul Ehrenfest received his education at the University of St. Petersburg
claims.gt_reason: Paul Ehrenfest received his education at the University of Vienna (doctorate 1904, under Boltzmann), not the University of St. Petersburg. He later lived and worked in St. Petersburg from 1907 to 1912, which may be the source of confusion.

claims.claim: Paul Ehrenfest worked as a research assistant at the University of St. Petersburg from 1909 to 1913
claims.gt_reason: Ehrenfest was in St. Petersburg from approximately 1907 to 1912, not 1909 to 1913. He also did not hold a 'research assistant' position — he worked independently without a formal university appointment, and left when he was offered the Leiden professorship in 1912.

claims.claim: Paul Ehrenfest moved to the University of Berlin from 1913 to 1915
claims.gt_reason: Paul Ehrenfest did not move to the University of Berlin. In 1912, he succeeded H.A. Lorentz at the University of Leiden (Netherlands), where he remained until his death in 1933. He never held a position at the University of Berlin.

claims.claim: Paul Ehrenfest held a professorship at the University of Göttingen from 1915 to 1921
claims.gt_reason: Paul Ehrenfest held a professorship at Leiden University (Universiteit Leiden) in the Netherlands, not the University of Göttingen. He succeeded Hendrik Lorentz at Leiden in 1912 and remained there until his death in 1933. He had no professorship at Göttingen.

claims.claim: Paul Ehrenfest became a professor at the University of Zurich from 1921 to 1925
claims.gt_reason: Paul Ehrenfest became a professor at Leiden University (University of Leiden) in the Netherlands in 1912, succeeding Lorentz, where he remained until his death in 1933. He was never a professor at the University of Zurich. It was Einstein who held a position at the University of Zurich (1909–1911) and ETH Zurich.

claims.claim: Paul Ehrenfest returned to the University of Göttingen from 1925 to 1933
claims.gt_reason: Paul Ehrenfest was a professor at Leiden University (Netherlands) from 1912 until his death in 1933. He never held a position at the University of Göttingen. He did visit Göttingen and other institutions, but his permanent academic home was Leiden, where he succeeded H.A. Lorentz.

claims.claim: Paul Ehrenfest's father was a prominent mathematician
claims.gt_reason: Paul Ehrenfest's father, Sigmund Ehrenfest, was a grocer/shopkeeper in Vienna, not a mathematician. Paul Ehrenfest himself became the prominent physicist and mathematician.

claims.claim: Ehrenfest taught at the University of Berlin from 1913 to 1915
claims.gt_reason: Paul Ehrenfest was appointed professor at Leiden University (University of Leiden) in the Netherlands in 1912, succeeding H.A. Lorentz. He held that position until his death in 1933. He never held a professorship at the University of Berlin. His connection to Berlin was through visits and conferences, not a faculty appointment.

claims.claim: Ehrenfest taught at the University of Zurich, Switzerland from 1921 to 1925
claims.gt_reason: Paul Ehrenfest did not teach at the University of Zurich from 1921 to 1925. He was a professor at Leiden University in the Netherlands from 1912 until his death in 1933, succeeding H.A. Lorentz. While he did visit other institutions, he held no professorship at the University of Zurich.

claims.claim: Ehrenfest taught at the University of Göttingen from 1925 to 1933
claims.gt_reason: Paul Ehrenfest was a professor at Leiden University in the Netherlands, a position he held from 1912 until his death in 1933. He never held a professorship at the University of Göttingen. Göttingen was associated with other prominent physicists of that era such as Max Born, David Hilbert, and Werner Heisenberg.

claims.claim: Lise Meitner was born in 1878
claims.gt_reason: Lise Meitner was born on November 7, 1878, in Vienna, Austria.

claims.claim: Lise Meitner died in 1968
claims.gt_reason: Lise Meitner died on October 27, 1968, in Cambridge, England, at the age of 89.

claims.claim: Lise Meitner was Austrian-German
claims.gt_reason: Lise Meitner was born in Vienna, Austria (1878) and spent much of her career in Germany (Berlin), making her Austrian-German. She later fled Nazi Germany in 1938 due to her Jewish heritage.

claims.claim: Meitner studied under Max Planck in Vienna
claims.gt_reason: Lise Meitner studied under Max Planck in Berlin, not Vienna. She moved to Berlin in 1907 to attend Planck's lectures at the University of Berlin, where she later became his assistant. Meitner had previously studied in Vienna (under Ludwig Boltzmann), but her work under Planck was in Berlin.

claims.claim: Meitner worked under Otto Hahn in Berlin
claims.gt_reason: Lise Meitner and Otto Hahn were long-term collaborators and co-equals at the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin, not in a supervisor-subordinate relationship where she worked 'under' him. They worked together as partners from 1907 onward. If anything, the hierarchy was complicated by gender discrimination that initially restricted Meitner's access, but Hahn was not her supervisor.

claims.claim: In 1938, Meitner and Otto Frisch calculated the energy released during nuclear fission
claims.gt_reason: Meitner and Frisch made their fission calculations in January 1939, not 1938. The fission of uranium was first achieved experimentally by Hahn and Strassmann in December 1938, but Meitner (who had fled Nazi Germany in July 1938) and her nephew Frisch worked out the theoretical explanation and energy calculations during Christmas 1938/New Year 1939, publishing their paper in February 1939.

claims.claim: The Meitner-Frisch paper was published in the journal Nature
claims.gt_reason: Lise Meitner and Otto Robert Frisch published their theoretical explanation of nuclear fission in the journal Nature in February 1939, titled 'Disintegration of Uranium by Neutrons: a New Type of Nuclear Reaction'.

claims.claim: The Meitner-Frisch paper was published on 28th July 1938
claims.gt_reason: The Meitner-Frisch paper explaining nuclear fission was published on 11 February 1939 in Nature, not July 1938. Lise Meitner and Otto Frisch conducted their theoretical analysis in January 1939 after Hahn and Strassmann's experimental results, and the paper appeared in the February 1939 issue of Nature.

claims.claim: The first successful nuclear chain reaction occurred in 1942
claims.gt_reason: The first successful artificial nuclear chain reaction was achieved on December 2, 1942, at Chicago Pile-1 (CP-1) under the University of Chicago's Stagg Field, led by Enrico Fermi as part of the Manhattan Project.

claims.claim: The Nobel Prize for nuclear fission was awarded to Otto Hahn and Fritz Strassmann
claims.gt_reason: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 1944 was awarded to Otto Hahn alone for the discovery of nuclear fission. Fritz Strassmann was not included, despite being Hahn's collaborator. Notably, Lise Meitner — who provided the theoretical explanation — was also excluded, widely considered one of history's most significant Nobel oversights.

claims.claim: Lise Meitner was never nominated for the Nobel Prize
claims.gt_reason: Lise Meitner was nominated for the Nobel Prize multiple times — at least 48 times across Physics and Chemistry — but never won. She is widely considered one of the most prominent examples of the Nobel Committee overlooking a deserving scientist. The 1944 Nobel Prize in Chemistry went solely to Otto Hahn for the discovery of nuclear fission, despite Meitner's crucial theoretical contributions.

claims.claim: Meitner received the title 'Pioneer of Nuclear Physics' from the International Atomic Energy Agency
claims.gt_reason: While Lise Meitner is widely recognized as a pioneer of nuclear physics, there is no verifiable record in my knowledge of the IAEA specifically awarding her a title called 'Pioneer of Nuclear Physics.' The claim may conflate informal recognition with a formal IAEA designation.

claims.claim: Otto Frisch was a collaborator and friend of Meitner
claims.gt_reason: Otto Frisch was Lise Meitner's nephew, and they collaborated closely on the theoretical explanation of nuclear fission in January 1939, famously working it out during a walk in the Swedish snow. Their relationship was both familial and professional.

claims.claim: Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar was an Indian-American theoretical astrophysicist
claims.gt_reason: Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar (1910–1995) was indeed an Indian-American theoretical astrophysicist. Born in Lahore (then British India), he emigrated to the United States and spent most of his career at the University of Chicago. He won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1983 for his work on stellar structure and evolution, including the Chandrasekhar limit.

claims.claim: Chandrasekhar won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1983
claims.gt_reason: Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1983, shared with William Alfred Fowler, for his theoretical studies of the physical processes important to the structure and evolution of stars, including his work on the Chandrasekhar limit.

claims.claim: The Chandrasekhar Limit is 1.44 times the mass of the Sun
claims.gt_reason: The Chandrasekhar Limit is approximately 1.4 solar masses, more precisely ~1.44 M☉, which is the maximum mass of a stable white dwarf star beyond which electron degeneracy pressure cannot support it against gravitational collapse.

claims.claim: Chandrasekhar published a paper titled 'The mass of a white dwarf star' in the Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society
claims.gt_reason: Chandrasekhar did publish papers on white dwarf stars in the Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society, but the exact title 'The mass of a white dwarf star' does not match his known publications. His canonical paper used the title 'The Maximum Mass of Ideal White Dwarfs'. Without web access to confirm whether this exact title exists, the claim cannot be fully verified or refuted.

claims.claim: The paper 'The mass of a white dwarf star' was published in 1930
claims.gt_reason: There is no single canonical paper with the exact title 'The mass of a white dwarf star.' Multiple researchers (e.g., Chandrasekhar, Eddington, others) published work on white dwarf masses around that era, but I cannot confirm a paper with that precise title was published in 1930 without risking a hallucinated attribution.

claims.claim: Chandrasekhar published a paper titled 'On the stability of white dwarfs' in the Astrophysical Journal
claims.gt_reason: While Chandrasekhar published extensively on white dwarf theory and stellar structure in the Astrophysical Journal during the 1930s-1940s, I cannot confirm with certainty that a paper with the exact title 'On the stability of white dwarfs' exists. His landmark work on the Chandrasekhar limit appeared in various forms, but verifying this precise title would require bibliographic confirmation.

claims.claim: The paper 'On the stability of white dwarfs' was published in 1931
claims.gt_reason: A paper with the exact title 'On the stability of white dwarfs' cannot be confirmed as published in 1931. Chandrasekhar's related foundational work 'The Maximum Mass of Ideal White Dwarfs' was published in 1931, but the precise title match is uncertain without access to a full bibliographic database.

claims.claim: Chandrasekhar published a paper titled 'On the evolution of stars' in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
claims.gt_reason: While Chandrasekhar published in PNAS and worked on stellar evolution topics, I cannot confirm the existence of a paper with the exact title 'On the evolution of stars' by Chandrasekhar in PNAS without access to a bibliographic database.

claims.claim: The paper 'On the evolution of stars' was published in 1946
claims.gt_reason: There is no widely known landmark paper with the exact title 'On the evolution of stars' that I can confidently associate with a 1946 publication date. Multiple papers on stellar evolution exist from that era, but without a specific author or journal reference, I cannot verify or refute this claim.

claims.claim: Treaty of Westphalia was signed between 1648 and 1649
claims.gt_reason: The Peace of Westphalia consisted of two treaties: the Treaty of Osnabrück and the Treaty of Münster, both signed on October 24, 1648. This falls within the stated range of 1648–1649.

claims.claim: Main signatories of the Treaty of Westphalia included the Holy Roman Emperor, the French king, and the Dutch Republic
claims.gt_reason: The Treaty of Westphalia (1648) was signed by the Holy Roman Emperor, France, and Sweden — not the Dutch Republic. The Dutch Republic (United Provinces) was involved in the Peace of Münster, one of the treaties comprising the Westphalian settlement, but primarily in the context of ending the Eighty Years' War with Spain. The main signatories of the broader Peace of Westphalia were the Holy Roman Empire, France, and Sweden. Sweden (not the Dutch Republic) was the key third major power.

claims.claim: Treaty of Tordesillas was signed in 1494
claims.gt_reason: The Treaty of Tordesillas was signed on June 7, 1494, between Spain and Portugal, dividing the newly discovered lands outside Europe between the two kingdoms.

claims.claim: Treaty of Tordesillas was signed by King Ferdinand II of Spain
claims.gt_reason: The Treaty of Tordesillas (1494) was signed by representatives of the Catholic Monarchs Ferdinand II of Aragon and Isabella I of Castile on the Spanish side, and King John II of Portugal on the other. Ferdinand II was not yet 'King of Spain' — that title did not exist in 1494; he was King of Aragon. More importantly, the treaty was not personally signed by Ferdinand himself but by his ambassadors/representatives. However, if the claim is interpreted loosely as Ferdinand being the Spanish monarch who authorized it, it is partially true but misleading since Isabella I of Castile held equal authority. The claim omits Isabella and misstates his title.

claims.claim: Treaty of Tordesillas was signed by Queen Isabella of Spain
claims.gt_reason: The Treaty of Tordesillas (1494) was signed by the Catholic Monarchs of Spain, Ferdinand II of Aragon and Isabella I of Castile, along with King John II of Portugal. Isabella was indeed a signatory.

claims.claim: Treaty of Tordesillas divided the New World between Spain and Portugal
claims.gt_reason: The Treaty of Tordesillas (1494) established a meridian line dividing newly discovered lands between Spain (west) and Portugal (east), granting Spain most of the Americas and Portugal what became Brazil and territories in Africa and Asia.

claims.claim: Treaty of Nerchinsk was signed in 1850
claims.gt_reason: The Treaty of Nerchinsk was signed in 1689, not 1850. It was the first treaty between Russia and China (Qing Dynasty), establishing borders in the Amur River region.

claims.claim: Treaty of Nerchinsk was signed by the Russian Empire and China
claims.gt_reason: The Treaty of Nerchinsk (1689) was signed by the Tsardom of Russia (not the Russian Empire, which was only proclaimed in 1721) and the Qing Dynasty of China.

claims.claim: Treaty of Nerchinsk was primarily focused on border demarcation
claims.gt_reason: The Treaty of Nerchinsk (1689) between Russia and Qing China was indeed primarily focused on border demarcation — it established the boundary along the Argun River and the Stanovoy Mountains, and included provisions for trade and the handling of fugitives, but border delimitation was its central purpose.

claims.claim: Peace of Augsburg was signed in 1555
claims.gt_reason: The Peace of Augsburg was signed on September 25, 1555, in Augsburg, establishing a principle of cuius regio, eius religio to resolve religious conflict between Catholic and Lutheran princes in the Holy Roman Empire.

claims.claim: Peace of Augsburg was signed by Holy Roman Emperor Charles V
claims.gt_reason: The Peace of Augsburg (1555) was not signed by Charles V personally. It was concluded by his brother Ferdinand I, who acted as his representative at the Diet of Augsburg. Charles V had already begun his abdication process and never personally ratified it; he abdicated in 1556. The agreement was reached in his name but executed by Ferdinand.

claims.claim: Peace of Augsburg established the principle of cuius regio, eius religio
claims.gt_reason: The Peace of Augsburg (1555) did establish the principle of cuius regio, eius religio ('whose realm, his religion'), allowing German princes to determine the official religion of their territories, choosing between Lutheranism and Catholicism.

claims.claim: Battle of Borodino had an estimated 40,000 to 60,000 total casualties including killed, wounded, and missing
claims.gt_reason: The Battle of Borodino (September 7, 1812) is generally estimated to have produced combined casualties of roughly 70,000–80,000 across both sides by many historians, but the range of 40,000–60,000 also appears in various sources depending on methodology and which categories are included. However, most mainstream historical estimates place total casualties higher — typically 70,000+ combined (French ~35,000, Russian ~45,000). The 40,000–60,000 range is on the low end and does not accurately reflect the scholarly consensus, making this claim incorrect.

claims.claim: Battle of Borodino took place on September 7, 1812
claims.gt_reason: The Battle of Borodino was fought on September 7, 1812 (New Style calendar) between Napoleon's Grande Armée and the Russian Imperial Army near the village of Borodino, during the French invasion of Russia. It is the deadliest single day of the Napoleonic Wars.

claims.claim: Marshal Soult commanded the French forces at the Battle of Borodino
claims.gt_reason: Marshal Soult did not command the French forces at the Battle of Borodino (1812). Napoleon Bonaparte personally commanded the French army at Borodino. Soult was present as a corps commander, but overall command rested with Napoleon. The Russian forces were commanded by Kutuzov.

claims.claim: General Davout was in charge of the Russian forces at the Battle of Borodino
claims.gt_reason: Marshal Louis-Nicolas Davout was a French commander at Borodino, not Russian. The Russian forces were commanded by General Mikhail Kutuzov. Davout commanded the I Corps of the French Grande Armée during the battle.

claims.claim: Battle of Tannenberg had an estimated 40,000 to 60,000 casualties for the German forces
claims.gt_reason: At the Battle of Tannenberg (August 1914), German forces under Hindenburg and Ludendorff achieved a decisive victory over the Russian Second Army. German casualties were approximately 10,000–15,000. It was the Russians who suffered catastrophic losses: roughly 50,000 killed or wounded and around 90,000–92,000 captured. The 40,000–60,000 casualty figure is far too high for the Germans and more loosely approximates a portion of Russian losses.

claims.claim: Battle of Tannenberg had an estimated 20,000 to 30,000 casualties for the Russian forces
claims.gt_reason: Russian casualties at the Battle of Tannenberg (1914) were far higher than 20,000–30,000. Estimates put killed and wounded at approximately 78,000, with around 92,000 prisoners taken, totaling roughly 170,000 casualties — effectively destroying the entire Russian Second Army.

claims.claim: Battle of Tannenberg took place on August 26, 1914
claims.gt_reason: The Battle of Tannenberg took place from August 26 to August 30, 1914 — it was a multi-day engagement, not a single day. If the claim intends to mark only the start date, that is accurate, but stating it 'took place on August 26, 1914' implies a single-day battle, which is misleading. The battle began on August 26 and concluded on August 30, 1914.

claims.claim: General Paul von Hindenburg commanded the German forces at the Battle of Tannenberg
claims.gt_reason: General Paul von Hindenburg, along with Chief of Staff Erich Ludendorff, commanded the German Eighth Army at the Battle of Tannenberg (August 1914), decisively defeating the Russian Second Army under General Samsonov.

claims.claim: General P.V. Krasnov commanded the Russian forces at the Battle of Tannenberg
claims.gt_reason: General Paul von Rennenkampf commanded the Russian First Army and General Alexander Samsonov commanded the Russian Second Army at the Battle of Tannenberg (August 1914). Samsonov's Second Army bore the brunt of the defeat. P.V. Krasnov was a Cossack general who served in WWI but did not command Russian forces at Tannenberg.

claims.claim: Battle of Zama took place in 202 BC
claims.gt_reason: The Battle of Zama took place in 202 BC near Zama, North Africa, where Scipio Africanus defeated Hannibal Barca, ending the Second Punic War.

claims.claim: Scipio Africanus commanded the Roman forces at the Battle of Zama
claims.gt_reason: Scipio Africanus (Publius Cornelius Scipio) commanded the Roman and allied forces at the Battle of Zama in 202 BC, defeating Hannibal Barca and ending the Second Punic War.

claims.claim: Hannibal Barca commanded the Carthaginian forces at the Battle of Zama
claims.gt_reason: parse error

claims.claim: Between 25,000 and 50,000 people died in the Siege of Constantinople
claims.gt_reason: Death toll estimates for the 1453 Siege of Constantinople vary widely across sources. Killed in battle and massacre estimates typically range from 4,000 to ~40,000, while ~50,000 were enslaved (not killed). The 25,000–50,000 deaths range is plausible for some broader interpretations but is not well-supported as a consensus figure and conflates deaths with enslavement.

claims.claim: The Siege of Constantinople occurred in 1453
claims.gt_reason: The Fall of Constantinople occurred in 1453 when Ottoman forces under Sultan Mehmed II besieged and captured the Byzantine capital, ending the Byzantine Empire.

claims.claim: Mehmed II was Sultan of the Ottoman Empire and commanded Ottoman forces at the Siege of Constantinople
claims.gt_reason: Mehmed II (also known as Mehmed the Conqueror) was indeed the Sultan of the Ottoman Empire and personally commanded Ottoman forces at the Siege of Constantinople in 1453, which resulted in the fall of the Byzantine Empire.

claims.claim: Emperor Constantine XI Palaiologos commanded the Byzantine forces at the Siege of Constantinople
claims.gt_reason: Constantine XI Palaiologos was indeed the last Byzantine Emperor and personally commanded the Byzantine defenders during the Ottoman siege of Constantinople in 1453. He died in the final assault on May 29, 1453.

claims.claim: The Royal Society was founded on 23 April 1660
claims.gt_reason: The Royal Society was founded on 28 November 1660, not 23 April 1660. That date in November is when a group of natural philosophers met at Gresham College in London and decided to found a society. It received its royal charter in 1662.

claims.claim: The Royal Society's original name was 'The Royal Society of London for Improving Natural Knowledge'
claims.gt_reason: The Royal Society's full official name is 'The Royal Society of London for Improving Natural Knowledge', but this was not its *original* name. When it was founded in 1660, it was informally called 'The Royal Society' or 'The College for the Promoting of Physico-Mathematical Experimental Learning'. The name 'The Royal Society of London for Improving Natural Knowledge' came with its royal charter in 1662. So the claim that this was its *original* name is incorrect.

claims.claim: Robert Boyle was a founding member of the Royal Society
claims.gt_reason: Robert Boyle was indeed one of the founding members of the Royal Society, which was established in 1660. He was among the group of natural philosophers who gathered at Gresham College and formed the foundation of what became the Royal Society, receiving its royal charter in 1662.

claims.claim: Robert Boyle was a physicist and chemist
claims.gt_reason: Robert Boyle (1627–1691) is historically recognized as both a physicist and chemist. He is best known for Boyle's Law (relating gas pressure and volume, a physics contribution) and for his foundational work in chemistry, including 'The Sceptical Chymist' (1661), which helped establish chemistry as a distinct scientific discipline.

claims.claim: Isaac Barrow was a founding member of the Royal Society
claims.gt_reason: Isaac Barrow was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society but was not a founding member. The Royal Society was founded in 1660 by figures such as Christopher Wren, Robert Boyle, and John Wilkins. Barrow was admitted as a Fellow in 1663 when the Society was formally chartered, not at its founding.

claims.claim: Isaac Barrow was a mathematician and physicist
claims.gt_reason: Isaac Barrow (1630–1677) was a mathematician and theologian, not a physicist. He was a prominent figure in mathematics (notably as Isaac Newton's predecessor as Lucasian Professor of Mathematics at Cambridge) and was also an ordained minister and theologian. Physics was not a recognized discipline in his era in the modern sense, and he is not historically categorized as a physicist.

claims.claim: Edmond Halley was a founding member of the Royal Society
claims.gt_reason: Edmond Halley (1656–1742) was not a founding member of the Royal Society. The Royal Society was founded in 1660, when Halley was only about 4 years old. He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1678 at age 22, and later served as its Secretary (1713–1721), but was not among its founders.

claims.claim: Edmond Halley was an astronomer
claims.gt_reason: Edmond Halley (1656–1742) was an English astronomer, mathematician, and physicist, best known for computing the orbit of the comet that bears his name (Halley's Comet). He served as Astronomer Royal from 1720 until his death.

claims.claim: Henry Oldenburg was a founding member of the Royal Society
claims.gt_reason: Henry Oldenburg was indeed a founding member of the Royal Society, established in 1660. He also served as its first Secretary and founded the Philosophical Transactions, one of the earliest scientific journals.

claims.claim: Henry Oldenburg was a historian and Secretary of the Royal Society
claims.gt_reason: Henry Oldenburg was not a historian. He was a diplomat and natural philosopher who served as the first Secretary of the Royal Society (from its founding in 1660 until his death in 1677). He is best known for founding and editing the Philosophical Transactions, the world's first scientific journal, and for his extensive scientific correspondence network.

claims.claim: Christopher Wren was a founding member of the Royal Society
claims.gt_reason: Christopher Wren was indeed one of the founding members of the Royal Society, established in 1660. He was among the group of natural philosophers who gathered at Gresham College and later formalized the organization, and served as its President from 1680 to 1682.

claims.claim: Christopher Wren was an architect
claims.gt_reason: Christopher Wren (1632–1723) was indeed an English architect, most famous for designing St. Paul's Cathedral in London and numerous other churches rebuilt after the Great Fire of London in 1666.

claims.claim: The Académie des Sciences was founded on 20 August 1666
claims.gt_reason: The Académie des Sciences was founded on 22 August 1666, not 20 August 1666. It held its first meeting on 22 August 1666 under the patronage of Louis XIV and his minister Jean-Baptiste Colbert.

claims.claim: The Académie des Sciences' original name was 'Académie Royale des Sciences'
claims.gt_reason: The Académie des Sciences was founded in 1666 under Louis XIV with the official name 'Académie Royale des Sciences'. It was renamed after the French Revolution, dropping 'Royale' from its title.

claims.claim: The American Philosophical Society was founded in 1743
claims.gt_reason: The American Philosophical Society was founded in Philadelphia in 1743 by Benjamin Franklin and others, making it the oldest learned society in the United States.

claims.claim: Benjamin Franklin was a founding member of the American Philosophical Society
claims.gt_reason: Benjamin Franklin co-founded the American Philosophical Society in 1743 in Philadelphia, making him not just a founding member but one of its principal founders. He also served as its president from 1769 until his death in 1790.

claims.claim: John Adams was a founding member of the American Philosophical Society
claims.gt_reason: The American Philosophical Society was founded in 1743 by Benjamin Franklin and others. John Adams was not among its founding members, though he did later become a member of the society.

claims.claim: John Adams became president of the United States
claims.gt_reason: John Adams served as the 2nd President of the United States from 1797 to 1801, succeeding George Washington.

claims.claim: Thomas Jefferson was a founding member of the American Philosophical Society
claims.gt_reason: Thomas Jefferson was a member and later president of the American Philosophical Society, but he was not a founding member. The APS was founded in 1743 by Benjamin Franklin and others. Jefferson joined later and served as its president from 1797 to 1815.

claims.claim: Thomas Jefferson became president of the United States
claims.gt_reason: Thomas Jefferson served as the 3rd President of the United States from 1801 to 1809.

claims.claim: William Smith was a founding member of the American Philosophical Society
claims.gt_reason: The American Philosophical Society was founded in 1743 by Benjamin Franklin and others. William Smith (Provost of the College of Philadelphia) was not among the founding members; he arrived in America in 1751 and was an early participant in the society's later reorganization, but is not credited as a founding member.

claims.claim: William Smith was a surveyor and cartographer
claims.gt_reason: William Smith (1769–1839) was an English geologist who worked as a surveyor and canal engineer, and is renowned for creating the first detailed geological map of England, Wales, and part of Scotland in 1815, making him both a surveyor and cartographer.

claims.claim: John Hancock was a founding member of the American Philosophical Society
claims.gt_reason: The American Philosophical Society was founded in 1743 by Benjamin Franklin and others including Francis Hopkinson, Hugh Roberts, Thomas Hopkinson, and John Bartram, among others. John Hancock was not among its founding members. Hancock was a prominent patriot and first governor of Massachusetts, but his association was with different organizations.

claims.claim: John Hancock was president of the Continental Congress
claims.gt_reason: John Hancock served as President of the Continental Congress from 1775 to 1777, making him the presiding officer when the Declaration of Independence was signed in 1776.

claims.claim: The Prussian Academy of Sciences was officially established in 1764
claims.gt_reason: The Prussian Academy of Sciences (Brandenburg Society of Sciences) was founded in 1700 by Leibniz under Elector Frederick III of Brandenburg. It was reorganized and renamed the Royal Prussian Academy of Sciences in 1744, not 1764.

claims.claim: The Prussian Academy of Sciences' original name was 'Akademie der Wissenschaften zu Berlin'
claims.gt_reason: The Prussian Academy of Sciences was founded in 1700 under the name 'Kurfürstlich Brandenburgische Societät der Wissenschaften' (Electoral Brandenburg Society of Sciences). 'Akademie der Wissenschaften zu Berlin' was a name used by its successor institution in the post-WWII era, not the original name.

claims.claim: The Prussian Academy of Sciences' first members were appointed by Frederick the Great
claims.gt_reason: The Prussian Academy of Sciences (Berlin Academy) was founded in 1700 by Frederick I (Elector Frederick III of Brandenburg), not Frederick the Great. Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz was appointed its first president. Frederick the Great (Frederick II) came to power in 1740, four decades later, and did reorganize and revitalize the Academy, but he did not appoint its first members.

claims.claim: Frederick the Great was the King of Prussia
claims.gt_reason: Frederick the Great (Frederick II) ruled as King of Prussia from 1740 to 1786, and is one of the most notable Prussian monarchs.

claims.claim: WFC3 wavelength range is 400-700 nm
claims.gt_reason: The Hubble Space Telescope's Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) covers a much broader wavelength range than 400-700 nm. Its UVIS channel covers approximately 200-1000 nm (ultraviolet through near-infrared), and its IR channel covers approximately 800-1700 nm. The claim's range of 400-700 nm describes only the visible light portion and understates WFC3's full spectral coverage.

claims.claim: WFC3 resolution is 0.1 arcseconds
claims.gt_reason: WFC3 (Wide Field Camera 3) on the Hubble Space Telescope has a pixel scale of approximately 0.04 arcseconds/pixel for the UVIS channel and 0.13 arcseconds/pixel for the IR channel. Neither matches 0.1 arcseconds/pixel. The claim is incorrect as stated, though 0.1 arcsec/pixel is roughly in the right ballpark for the IR channel.

claims.claim: WFC3 field of view is approximately 10 arcminutes
claims.gt_reason: The Hubble Space Telescope's Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) has a field of view of approximately 2.7 × 2.7 arcminutes (UVIS channel) or 2.2 × 1.4 arcminutes (IR channel), not 10 arcminutes.

claims.claim: WFC3 full field of view is 15 arcminutes
claims.gt_reason: The HST WFC3 has two channels with different fields of view: the UVIS channel covers approximately 162×162 arcseconds (~2.7×2.7 arcminutes), and the IR channel covers approximately 123×136 arcseconds (~2×2.3 arcminutes). Neither channel has a 15 arcminute field of view. 15 arcminutes is far larger than WFC3's actual FOV.

claims.claim: WFC3 spectral resolution is approximately 30% per pixel
claims.gt_reason: WFC3 (Wide Field Camera 3) on the Hubble Space Telescope has spectral resolution that depends on the grism used. The G141 grism has R~130 and the G102 grism has R~210 (both at reference wavelengths). Spectral resolution is typically expressed as R = λ/Δλ, not as a percentage per pixel. The dispersion is roughly 46 Å/pixel for G141 and 24 Å/pixel for G102. '30% per pixel' is not a standard or meaningful way to express spectral resolution, and no such figure corresponds to known WFC3 specifications.

claims.claim: COS wavelength range is 0.3-1.7 microns
claims.gt_reason: COS (Cosmic Origins Spectrograph) on HST operates in the ultraviolet, approximately 115–320 nm (0.115–0.320 microns), not 0.3–1.7 microns. The claimed range is off by roughly an order of magnitude and extends far into the near-infrared, which COS does not cover.

claims.claim: COS high resolution is approximately 0.01 arcseconds
claims.gt_reason: COS (Cosmic Origins Spectrograph on HST) is a UV spectrograph, not an imager. Its spatial resolution is on the order of ~0.1 arcseconds, not 0.01 arcseconds. The 0.01 arcsecond figure is more characteristic of HST imaging instruments or diffraction-limited performance at shorter wavelengths, not COS specifically.

claims.claim: COS low resolution is approximately 0.1 arcseconds
claims.gt_reason: COS (Cosmic Origins Spectrograph) is primarily a spectrograph; 'low resolution' in COS context refers to spectral resolution modes (R~1,500-4,000), not angular resolution. If referring to angular/spatial resolution, ~0.1 arcseconds is plausible for HST instruments generally, but this framing is non-standard for COS. The claim is ambiguous and cannot be definitively verified or refuted without more context.

claims.claim: COS field of view is approximately 5 arcseconds
claims.gt_reason: The COS (Cosmic Origins Spectrograph) Primary Science Aperture has a diameter of 2.5 arcseconds, not approximately 5 arcseconds. COS is a point-source spectrograph, not an imager, and its aperture is ~2.5 arcsec in diameter.

claims.claim: COS spectral resolution is approximately 20% per pixel
claims.gt_reason: The Hubble Space Telescope's Cosmic Origins Spectrograph (COS) has a spectral resolution of R ~ 20,000 for the medium-resolution modes (FUV) and R ~ 2,000–3,000 for low-resolution modes. Spectral resolution is expressed as R = λ/Δλ (a dimensionless ratio), not as a percentage per pixel. The claim conflates or misrepresents the concept — 'approximately 20% per pixel' is not a standard or correct way to express spectral resolution for COS or any spectrograph.

claims.claim: STIS wavelength range is 1100-1700 nm
claims.gt_reason: The Hubble Space Telescope's Space Telescope Imaging Spectrograph (STIS) covers a wavelength range from approximately 115 nm to 1030 nm (UV through near-infrared), not 1100-1700 nm. The claim's range is entirely outside STIS's actual coverage and would fall in the near-infrared, which STIS does not reach.

claims.claim: STIS high resolution is approximately 0.05 arcseconds
claims.gt_reason: The Hubble Space Telescope's Space Telescope Imaging Spectrograph (STIS) achieves angular resolution of approximately 0.05-0.1 arcseconds, depending on the mode. The stated ~0.05 arcseconds is within the correct range for STIS high-resolution observations, consistent with HST's diffraction limit at UV/optical wavelengths.

claims.claim: STIS low resolution is approximately 0.2 arcseconds
claims.gt_reason: The Hubble Space Telescope's Space Telescope Imaging Spectrograph (STIS) in low-resolution mode refers to its spectral resolution, not spatial resolution. STIS has a spatial resolution of approximately 0.05–0.1 arcseconds (limited by HST's diffraction and detector pixel scale of ~0.05 arcsec/pixel). The spectral low-resolution modes (e.g., G140L, G230L, G430L, G750L) have resolving powers of ~1,000, not an angular measurement. If the claim refers to spatial resolution, ~0.2 arcseconds overstates the PSF size for STIS on HST. The claim as stated is not a standard characterization of STIS low-resolution capabilities.

claims.claim: STIS field of view is approximately 10 arcseconds
claims.gt_reason: STIS fields of view are approximately 52x52 arcseconds for the CCD detector and 25x25 arcseconds for the MAMA detectors. No standard STIS observing mode has a ~10 arcsecond field of view.

claims.claim: STIS spectral resolution high is approximately 10% per pixel
claims.gt_reason: STIS (Space Telescope Imaging Spectrograph) high spectral resolution modes achieve resolving power R up to ~100,000–200,000, corresponding to velocity resolution of ~1–3 km/s per resolution element, not 10% per pixel. A '10% per pixel' figure is not a standard or meaningful way to describe spectral resolution, and no STIS mode matches such a description. STIS gratings span a wide range of resolutions, but the high-resolution echelle modes have dispersion on the order of milliangstroms per pixel, not 10% per pixel.

claims.claim: Francium has a melting point of approximately 27°C (81°F)
claims.gt_reason: Francium's melting point is approximately 27°C (80.6°F / 300 K), which is consistent with the claim. This is well-established, though direct measurement is difficult due to francium's extreme rarity and radioactivity.

claims.claim: Francium has a boiling point of approximately 70°C (158°F)
claims.gt_reason: Francium's boiling point is approximately 677°C (1251°F), not 70°C. The figure 70°C is closer to francium's melting point, which is estimated at around 27°C (80°F). The claim confuses or misrepresents the boiling point by an order of magnitude.

claims.claim: Francium has a density of approximately 2.9 g/cm³
claims.gt_reason: Francium's density is estimated at approximately 1.87 g/cm³, not 2.9 g/cm³. As an alkali metal, it follows the trend of relatively low densities in Group 1 elements.

claims.claim: Francium has an electronegativity estimated around 0.7
claims.gt_reason: Francium's Pauling electronegativity is estimated at 0.7, making it the least electronegative element known. This is consistent with its position as the most electropositive alkali metal.

claims.claim: Astatine has a melting point of approximately -71°C (180°F)
claims.gt_reason: Astatine's melting point is approximately 302°C (576°F), not -71°C. The value -71°C is close to the boiling point of nitrogen or similar cryogenic substances, not astatine, which is a heavy halogen with a high melting point consistent with the trend down Group 17.

claims.claim: Astatine has a boiling point of approximately -71°C (180°F)
claims.gt_reason: Astatine's boiling point is approximately 337°C (639°F), not -71°C. The value -71°C is close to the boiling point of chlorine (-34°C) or bromine (59°C), not astatine, which is the heaviest stable halogen and has a much higher boiling point consistent with its position in the halogen group.

claims.claim: Astatine has a density of approximately 1.4 g/cm³
claims.gt_reason: Astatine's density is estimated at approximately 6.2–6.4 g/cm³, not 1.4 g/cm³. It is a heavy halogen (atomic number 85), and its density is far greater than 1.4 g/cm³, which would be closer to some light metals or plastics.

claims.claim: Astatine has an electronegativity estimated around 0.7
claims.gt_reason: Astatine's electronegativity is estimated at approximately 2.2 on the Pauling scale, not 0.7. A value of 0.7 would place it near the least electronegative elements like cesium (0.79) or francium (0.7), which is inconsistent with astatine being a halogen.

claims.claim: Oganesson's melting point has not been measured experimentally
claims.gt_reason: Oganesson (element 118) is a superheavy element with an extremely short half-life (the most stable isotope, Og-294, has a half-life of about 0.7 milliseconds), making experimental measurement of bulk physical properties like melting point impossible with current technology. Only a few atoms have ever been synthesized. Any values cited are purely theoretical predictions.

claims.claim: Oganesson's boiling point has not been measured experimentally
claims.gt_reason: Oganesson (element 118) is a superheavy synthetic element with an extremely short half-life (the most stable isotope, Og-294, has a half-life of about 0.7 milliseconds). Only a handful of atoms have ever been produced, making experimental measurement of bulk physical properties like boiling point impossible. Any values cited in the literature are theoretical predictions from computational chemistry.

claims.claim: Oganesson's density has not been measured experimentally
claims.gt_reason: Oganesson (element 118) is a superheavy synthetic element with an extremely short half-life (~0.89 ms for the most stable isotope, Og-294). Only a handful of atoms have ever been produced, making experimental measurement of bulk physical properties like density impossible. Its density (~4.9–5 g/cm³ by some theoretical predictions, though others suggest it may behave unusually due to relativistic effects) is theoretical/computational only.

claims.claim: Oganesson has an electronegativity estimated around 0.7
claims.gt_reason: Oganesson's electronegativity is theoretically estimated at approximately 0.86 on the Pauling scale, not 0.7. While precise values are uncertain due to the element's synthetic nature, 0.7 does not match the standard theoretical prediction.

claims.claim: Tennessine's melting point has not been measured experimentally
claims.gt_reason: Tennessine (element 117) is a superheavy synthetic element with an extremely short half-life (the most stable isotope, Ts-294, has a half-life of about 51 milliseconds). Only a handful of atoms have ever been produced, making experimental measurement of bulk physical properties like melting point impossible. Any values cited are purely theoretical predictions.

claims.claim: Tennessine's boiling point has not been measured experimentally
claims.gt_reason: Tennessine (element 117) is a superheavy synthetic element with extremely short-lived isotopes (longest-lived has a half-life of ~51 milliseconds), making experimental measurement of bulk physical properties like boiling point impossible with current technology. Any reported values are theoretical predictions only.

claims.claim: Tennessine's density has not been measured experimentally
claims.gt_reason: Tennessine (element 117) is a superheavy synthetic element that has only been produced in extremely small quantities (a few atoms at a time) with half-lives of milliseconds to tens of milliseconds. No macroscopic sample has ever been produced, making experimental density measurement impossible. The cited density (~7.17 g/cm³) is a theoretical prediction only.

claims.claim: Tennessine has an electronegativity estimated around 0.7
claims.gt_reason: Tennessine's electronegativity is theoretically estimated around 2.58 on the Pauling scale, consistent with its position as a group 17 halogen. A value of 0.7 would be characteristic of the most electropositive alkali/alkaline metals, not a halogen.

claims.claim: Francium is highly radioactive
claims.gt_reason: Francium is indeed highly radioactive. It is the most unstable of the naturally occurring elements, with its most stable isotope (francium-223) having a half-life of only about 22 minutes. All isotopes of francium are radioactive.

claims.claim: Astatine is highly radioactive
claims.gt_reason: Astatine (At, element 85) is indeed highly radioactive. It is the rarest naturally occurring element on Earth, with no stable isotopes. Its most stable isotope, astatine-210, has a half-life of only about 8.1 hours. All astatine isotopes undergo radioactive decay rapidly.

claims.claim: Oganesson is highly radioactive
claims.gt_reason: Oganesson (element 118) is a synthetic superheavy element with no stable isotopes. Its most stable known isotope, Og-294, has a half-life of approximately 0.7 milliseconds, making it highly radioactive by any measure.

claims.claim: Tennessine is highly radioactive
claims.gt_reason: Tennessine (element 117) is a synthetic superheavy element with no stable isotopes. All known isotopes are highly radioactive with extremely short half-lives (the longest-lived isotope, Ts-294, has a half-life of about 51 milliseconds), decaying via alpha decay or spontaneous fission.

claims.claim: Voyager 1 carries a Magnetometer instrument
claims.gt_reason: Voyager 1 does carry a Magnetometer (MAG) instrument, which has been used to study magnetic fields in the solar system and interstellar space. This is well-documented NASA mission data.

claims.claim: Voyager 1 carries a Plasma Science Instrument
