claims.gt_reason: Voyager 1 does carry a Plasma Science instrument (PLS), which was used to study the properties of the solar wind plasma. Note that the PLS stopped returning usable data in 1980 after the spacecraft's antenna pointing changed following the Saturn flyby, but the instrument is aboard the spacecraft.

claims.claim: Voyager 1 carries a Cosmic Ray Detector
claims.gt_reason: Voyager 1 carries a Cosmic Ray Subsystem (CRS) instrument designed to measure cosmic rays. It was one of the original science instruments on the spacecraft launched in 1977 and remains operational, providing data on cosmic rays in interstellar space.

claims.claim: Voyager 1 carries a Radio Science Experiment
claims.gt_reason: Voyager 1 does carry a Radio Science System (RSS), which is one of its scientific instruments. It uses the spacecraft's radio transmitters to study planetary atmospheres, ring structures, and gravitational fields by analyzing how radio signals are affected as the spacecraft passes behind celestial bodies or through planetary systems.

claims.claim: Voyager 1 carries a Visual Imaging System
claims.gt_reason: Voyager 1 does not carry a Visual Imaging System (VIS). It carried a pair of Vidicon television cameras as part of its Imaging Science Subsystem (ISS). The term 'Visual Imaging System' is not the correct name for any instrument on Voyager 1. Note: the cameras were also powered down in 1990 after the 'Family Portrait' images. A 'Visual Imaging System' is associated with other missions, such as Cassini's VIMS (Visual and Infrared Mapping Spectrometer) or the term is sometimes confused with other spacecraft instruments.

claims.claim: Voyager 1 transmits data back to Earth using radio signals
claims.gt_reason: Voyager 1 communicates with Earth via radio waves transmitted through NASA's Deep Space Network. It uses an S-band and X-band radio system operating at approximately 8 GHz, with signals taking over 22 hours to travel one way at this distance.

claims.claim: Voyager 1 data is received and analyzed by scientists at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL)
claims.gt_reason: NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California manages the Voyager mission and is where scientists receive and analyze data from Voyager 1. JPL has managed the Voyager program since launch in 1977.

claims.claim: Voyager 1 is powered by a radioisotope thermoelectric generator (RTG)
claims.gt_reason: Voyager 1 is powered by three MHW-RTG (Multi-Hundred Watt Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generator) units, which convert heat from the decay of plutonium-238 into electricity. This is well-established fact.

claims.claim: The RTG converts heat from radioactive decay into electricity
claims.gt_reason: Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generators (RTGs) use thermoelectric materials to convert heat generated by radioactive decay (typically of plutonium-238) into electricity via the Seebeck effect. This is a well-established technology used in spacecraft like Voyager, Cassini, and Mars rovers.

claims.claim: The primary objectives of the Voyager 1 mission were to study the outer planets of our solar system and explore the interstellar medium
claims.gt_reason: The primary objectives of Voyager 1 were to study Jupiter and Saturn (and their moons and rings). Interstellar medium exploration was not a primary objective — it became a long-term extended mission goal only after the planetary flybys were complete. The mission was not originally designed to 'explore the interstellar medium' as a primary goal.

claims.claim: The Voyager 1 mission has been ongoing for decades
claims.gt_reason: Voyager 1 launched on September 5, 1977, and remains operational as of 2026, making it an ongoing mission of nearly 49 years.

claims.claim: NASA's Voyager 1 Mission website is https://voyager.jpl.nasa.gov/
claims.gt_reason: NASA's Voyager mission website is hosted at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory domain. The URL voyager.jpl.nasa.gov is the well-established official URL for the Voyager mission, consistent with JPL's standard subdomain pattern for missions they manage.

claims.claim: Tevatron main ring beam energy is 1.02 TeV
claims.gt_reason: The Tevatron's beam energy was 980 GeV (0.98 TeV) per beam, not 1.02 TeV. The Main Ring was a separate, lower-energy injector synchrotron operating at ~150 GeV, not 1.02 TeV.

claims.claim: Tevatron booster ring beam energy is 350 GeV
claims.gt_reason: The Fermilab Booster accelerated protons to 8 GeV, not 350 GeV. The Tevatron itself reached ~980 GeV per beam, while the Main Injector operated at ~150 GeV. 350 GeV does not correspond to any standard Tevatron Booster energy.

claims.claim: Tevatron luminosity is approximately 10^33 cm^-2s^-1
claims.gt_reason: The Tevatron's peak instantaneous luminosity reached approximately 4×10^32 cm^-2s^-1, which is on the order of 10^33 cm^-2s^-1. Describing it as 'approximately 10^33' is a reasonable order-of-magnitude characterization, though the more precise value is ~4×10^32 cm^-2s^-1.

claims.claim: Tevatron circumference is approximately 1.2 km
claims.gt_reason: The Tevatron at Fermilab had a circumference of approximately 6.3 km (3.9 miles), not 1.2 km.

claims.claim: Super Proton Synchrotron (SPS) main ring beam energy is 400 GeV at peak operation
claims.gt_reason: The SPS peak beam energy is 450 GeV (used when injecting into the LHC), not 400 GeV. The 400 GeV figure applies to fixed-target operation modes, not peak operation.

claims.claim: SPS luminosity is approximately 10^33 cm^-2s^-1
claims.gt_reason: The CERN Super Proton Synchrotron (SPS) operates as a fixed-target accelerator and injector, not a collider with high luminosity. Its luminosity as a fixed-target machine is not characterized the same way as a collider. The LHC, by contrast, operates at luminosities around 10^34 cm^-2s^-1 (design) and has reached ~10^34–10^35 cm^-2s^-1 in high-luminosity runs. The SPS has been used in collider mode (SppS) historically, achieving peak luminosities around 10^30 cm^-2s^-1, far below 10^33. The value 10^33 cm^-2s^-1 is more associated with earlier LHC runs or the Tevatron, not the SPS.

claims.claim: SPS circumference is approximately 10.2 km
claims.gt_reason: The CERN Super Proton Synchrotron (SPS) has a circumference of approximately 6.9 km (6,911 meters), not 10.2 km. The 10.2 km figure does not correspond to any major CERN accelerator; the LHC is ~27 km and the LEP/LHC tunnel is 26.7 km.

claims.claim: KEKB main ring initial operation beam energy is 200 GeV
claims.gt_reason: KEKB is an asymmetric electron-positron collider located at KEK in Japan. Its beam energies are approximately 8 GeV for the high-energy ring (HER, electrons) and 3.5 GeV for the low-energy ring (LER, positrons), designed to produce Υ(4S) resonance at ~10.58 GeV center-of-mass energy. 200 GeV is far beyond its actual operating range.

claims.claim: KEKB reached up to 300 GeV beam energy
claims.gt_reason: KEKB was an asymmetric electron-positron collider operating at much lower energies — electrons at 8 GeV and positrons at 3.5 GeV, designed to produce B mesons at the Υ(4S) resonance (~10.58 GeV center-of-mass energy). 300 GeV is far beyond its design parameters.

claims.claim: KEKB luminosity is approximately 10^34 cm^-2s^-1
claims.gt_reason: KEKB achieved a peak luminosity of ~2.11 × 10^34 cm^-2s^-1, which is approximately 10^34 cm^-2s^-1 in order of magnitude. The claim is correct.

claims.claim: KEKB circumference is approximately 26 km
claims.gt_reason: KEKB (the electron-positron collider at KEK in Tsukuba, Japan) has a circumference of approximately 3 km (3,016 meters), not 26 km. The 26 km figure is closer to the circumference of CERN's Large Hadron Collider (LHC), which is about 27 km.

claims.claim: RHIC gold ion beam energy is 200 GeV/nucleon
claims.gt_reason: RHIC collides gold ions at 200 GeV per nucleon pair (i.e., 100 GeV per nucleon per beam), giving a center-of-mass energy of √s_NN = 200 GeV. The beam energy per nucleon is 100 GeV, not 200 GeV. The 200 GeV figure refers to the center-of-mass collision energy per nucleon pair, not the beam energy per nucleon.

claims.claim: RHIC lead ion beam energy is 200 GeV/nucleon
claims.gt_reason: RHIC (Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider) collides gold (Au) ions, not lead ions. Its top energy for gold-gold collisions is 200 GeV per nucleon (center-of-mass energy). Lead ions are used at CERN's LHC/SPS, not RHIC. The energy figure of 200 GeV/nucleon is associated with RHIC gold collisions, not lead ions.

claims.claim: RHIC luminosity is approximately 10^34 cm^-2s^-1
claims.gt_reason: RHIC (Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider) peak luminosity is approximately 10^32 cm^-2s^-1 for gold-gold collisions, which is about two orders of magnitude lower than the claimed 10^34 cm^-2s^-1. The value 10^34 cm^-2s^-1 is more characteristic of the LHC's design luminosity for proton-proton collisions.

claims.claim: RHIC circumference is approximately 2.4 km
claims.gt_reason: The Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) at Brookhaven National Laboratory has a circumference of approximately 3.8 km (3,834 meters), not 2.4 km.

claims.claim: Shannon's 'A Mathematical Theory of Communication' was published in the Bell System Technical Journal
claims.gt_reason: Claude Shannon's 'A Mathematical Theory of Communication' was published in the Bell System Technical Journal in 1948 (volumes 27, pp. 379–423 and 623–656, July and October 1948).

claims.claim: Shannon's 'A Mathematical Theory of Communication' was published in volume 27

claims.claim: Shannon's 'A Mathematical Theory of Communication' was published in 1948

claims.gt_reason: Einstein's 1905 paper on the Photoelectric Effect ('On a Heuristic Point of View Concerning the Production and Transformation of Light') was published in Annalen der Physik, Volume 17, not Volume 324. claims.gt_reason: Einstein's 1905 paper on mass-energy equivalence ('Ist die Trägheit eines Körpers von seinem Energieinhalt abhängig?') was published in Annalen der Physik, Volume 18 (1905), not Volume 326.

claims.claim: Watson and Crick's paper is titled 'Molecular Structure of Nucleic Acids: A Structure for Deoxyribose Nucleic Acid'

claims.claim: Watson and Crick's paper was authored by James Watson and Francis Crick
claims.gt_reason: The 1953 Nature paper 'Molecular Structure of Nucleic Acids: A Structure for Deoxyribose Nucleic Acid' was indeed authored by James D. Watson and Francis H.C. Crick.

claims.claim: Watson and Crick's paper was published in Nature
claims.gt_reason: Watson and Crick's landmark paper 'Molecular Structure of Nucleic Acids: A Structure for Deoxyribose Nucleic Acid' was published in Nature on April 25, 1953.

claims.claim: Watson and Crick's paper was published on 28th April 1953
claims.gt_reason: Watson and Crick's paper 'Molecular Structure of Nucleic Acids: A Structure for Deoxyribose Nucleic Acid' was published in Nature on 25 April 1953, not 28 April 1953.

claims.claim: Watson and Crick's paper appears on pages 715-730 of the 1953 Nature volume
claims.gt_reason: Watson and Crick's 1953 DNA paper was published in Nature Vol. 171 on pages 737–738, not pages 715–730.

claims.claim: Rosalind Franklin's paper is titled 'The Constitution of the DNA Molecule'

Her key 1953 paper on DNA structure was titled 'Molecular Configuration in Sodium Thymonucleate', published in Nature alongside the Watson & Crick and Wilkins et al. papers. The fabricated title does not correspond to any known Franklin publication.

claims.claim: Rosalind Franklin's paper was published in Nature
claims.gt_reason: Rosalind Franklin co-authored a paper published in Nature on April 25, 1953, alongside Raymond Gosling. It appeared in the same issue as the Watson and Crick double helix paper, presenting X-ray diffraction evidence supporting the helical structure of DNA.

claims.claim: Rosalind Franklin's paper was published in 1952
claims.gt_reason: Rosalind Franklin's key X-ray crystallography papers on DNA were published in 1953, in the same issue of Nature (Vol. 171, April 25, 1953) as Watson and Crick's double helix paper and Wilkins et al.'s paper. Her 1952 work was unpublished research/data that was shared without her knowledge.

claims.claim: The Meselson-Stahl experiment paper is titled 'DNA Replication and the Genetic Code'
claims.gt_reason: The Meselson-Stahl experiment paper (1958) is titled 'The Replication of DNA in Escherichia coli', published in PNAS. 'DNA Replication and the Genetic Code' is not the title of that paper.

claims.claim: Matthew Meselson is an author of the Meselson-Stahl experiment paper
claims.gt_reason: Matthew Meselson and Franklin Stahl co-authored the 1958 paper 'The Replication of DNA in Escherichia coli' published in PNAS, which described the Meselson-Stahl experiment demonstrating semi-conservative DNA replication.

claims.claim: Gödel's paper was published in 1931
claims.gt_reason: Kurt Gödel's incompleteness theorems were published in 1931 in the paper 'Über formal unentscheidbare Sätze der Principia Mathematica und verwandter Systeme I' (On Formally Undecidable Propositions of Principia Mathematica and Related Systems I).

claims.claim: The author of the incompleteness theorems paper is Kurt Gödel
claims.gt_reason: Kurt Gödel published his incompleteness theorems in 1931 in his paper 'Über formal unentscheidbare Sätze der Principia Mathematica und verwandter Systeme' (On Formally Undecidable Propositions of Principia Mathematica and Related Systems).

claims.claim: Gödel's paper title is 'On the consistency of the axioms of Peano arithmetic'
claims.gt_reason: Gödel's famous 1931 paper is titled 'Über formal unentscheidbare Sätze der Principia Mathematica und verwandter Systeme' ('On Formally Undecidable Propositions of Principia Mathematica and Related Systems'). It concerns incompleteness, not consistency of Peano arithmetic. The claim conflates this with a different result — Gödel's second incompleteness theorem shows Peano arithmetic *cannot* prove its own consistency, which is nearly the opposite of what the fabricated title implies.

claims.claim: Gödel's paper was published in the Journal für die reine und angewandte Mathematik
claims.gt_reason: Gödel's 1931 incompleteness theorems paper was published in 'Monatshefte für Mathematik und Physik', not the 'Journal für die reine und angewandte Mathematik' (Crelle's Journal).

claims.claim: The Cook-Levin theorem paper was published in 1971
claims.gt_reason: The Cook-Levin theorem, proving that SAT is NP-complete, was established in 1971. Stephen Cook published 'The Complexity of Theorem Proving Procedures' at the 1971 ACM Symposium on Theory of Computing (STOC). Leonid Levin independently developed the same result around the same time (published 1973 in Russian literature, but the work was done in 1971-1972).

claims.claim: The authors of the Cook-Levin theorem paper are Stephen Cook and Michael Levin
claims.gt_reason: The Cook-Levin theorem was independently proven by Stephen Cook (in his 1971 paper 'The Complexity of Theorem Proving Procedures') and Leonid Levin (a Soviet mathematician, published 1973). The 'Levin' in Cook-Levin is Leonid Levin, not Michael Levin.

claims.claim: The Cook-Levin theorem paper title is 'Reducibility of problems to Turing machines'
claims.gt_reason: The Cook-Levin theorem consists of two separate papers. Stephen Cook's 1971 paper is titled 'The Complexity of Theorem Proving Procedures'. Leonid Levin's paper is titled 'Universal search problems' (1973). Neither is titled 'Reducibility of problems to Turing machines'.

claims.claim: The Cook-Levin theorem paper was published in The Journal of the ACM
claims.gt_reason: Cook's 1971 paper 'The Complexity of Theorem Proving Procedures' was published in the Proceedings of the 3rd Annual ACM Symposium on Theory of Computing (STOC), not The Journal of the ACM. Levin's independent work was published in a Soviet journal (Problemy Peredachi Informatsii).

claims.claim: Andrew Wiles's proof of Fermat's Last Theorem was published in 1994
claims.gt_reason: Andrew Wiles's proof of Fermat's Last Theorem was published in the journal Annals of Mathematics in 1995, but the proof was announced and a preprint circulated in 1993, with the corrected final proof completed in 1994. The 1994 date refers to when the corrected proof was finalized, making this claim correct in common usage.

claims.claim: The author of the Fermat's Last Theorem proof is Andrew Wiles
claims.gt_reason: Andrew Wiles proved Fermat's Last Theorem in 1995, publishing the complete proof in Annals of Mathematics after fixing a gap identified in his 1993 announcement. He received the Abel Prize in 2016 for this work.

claims.claim: Wiles's paper title is 'Modular forms, elliptic curves, and Fermat's Last Theorem'
claims.gt_reason: Wiles's 1995 Annals of Mathematics paper is titled 'Modular elliptic curves and Fermat's Last Theorem'. The title in the claim transposes/alters the wording.

claims.claim: Wiles's paper was published in The Journal of the American Mathematical Society
claims.gt_reason: Andrew Wiles's 1995 proof of Fermat's Last Theorem was published in the Annals of Mathematics, not The Journal of the American Mathematical Society. The paper 'Modular elliptic curves and Fermat's Last Theorem' appeared in Annals of Mathematics, Vol. 141, No. 3 (May 1995), alongside a companion paper by Taylor and Wiles.

claims.claim: Emmy Noether was born in 1882
claims.gt_reason: Emmy Noether was born on March 23, 1882, in Erlangen, Bavaria, Germany.

claims.claim: Emmy Noether died in 1935
claims.gt_reason: Emmy Noether died on April 14, 1935, in Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania, from complications following surgery.

claims.claim: Emmy Noether was German
claims.gt_reason: Emmy Noether (1882–1935) was born in Erlangen, Bavaria, Germany, and was a German mathematician known for her foundational contributions to abstract algebra and theoretical physics.

claims.claim: Emmy Noether studied mathematics at the University of Erlangen from 1901 to 1905
claims.gt_reason: Emmy Noether audited courses at the University of Erlangen from 1900, officially enrolled when women were permitted in 1904, and received her PhD in 1907. The 1901–1905 timeframe for her studies there is accurate.

claims.claim: Emmy Noether earned a diploma in mathematics from the University of Erlangen in 1905-1907
claims.gt_reason: Emmy Noether was not awarded a diploma in mathematics from Erlangen. She passed her teacher's examination (Lehrerinnenprüfung) in 1900, then audited lectures at Erlangen (women couldn't formally enroll), and received her PhD from the University of Erlangen in 1907 — not a diploma. The claim conflates the timeframe and mischaracterizes the credential.

claims.claim: Hermann Minkowski was one of Noether's doctoral advisors at the University of Erlangen
claims.gt_reason: Emmy Noether completed her doctorate at the University of Erlangen in 1907 under Paul Gordan. Hermann Minkowski was never her doctoral advisor. Minkowski was a professor at Göttingen (where Noether later worked), not Erlangen, and he died in 1909.

claims.claim: Hermann Weyl was a student of Noether's at the University of Göttingen
claims.gt_reason: Hermann Weyl and Emmy Noether were contemporaries and colleagues at the University of Göttingen, not in a student-teacher relationship. Weyl was a student of David Hilbert, not Noether. Weyl received his doctorate in 1908 under Hilbert, while Noether arrived at Göttingen later (around 1915). They were peers who mutually respected each other's work.

claims.claim: Lise Meitner was mentored by Noether
claims.gt_reason: Lise Meitner was mentored by Max Planck, not Emmy Noether. Meitner worked under Planck at the University of Berlin starting in 1907. Noether was a mathematician, while Meitner was a physicist — their fields overlapped minimally. There is no historical record of a mentorship relationship between them.

claims.claim: Lise Meitner was a nuclear physicist
claims.gt_reason: Lise Meitner (1878–1968) was an Austrian-Swedish nuclear physicist who, along with Otto Hahn and Fritz Strassmann, discovered nuclear fission in 1938. She is widely recognized as a pioneering nuclear physicist.

claims.claim: Noether was at the University of Göttingen from 1907 to 1919
claims.gt_reason: Emmy Noether was at the University of Göttingen from 1915 to 1933 (when she was expelled by the Nazis). Before that, she was at the University of Erlangen from 1908 to 1915. She visited Göttingen briefly in 1903–1904, but her substantive affiliation began in 1915 when Hilbert and Klein invited her, not 1907.

claims.claim: Noether was at the University of Berlin from 1920 to 1923
claims.gt_reason: Emmy Noether was at the University of Göttingen, not Berlin. She joined Göttingen in 1915 (invited by Hilbert and Klein) and remained there until 1933 when she was dismissed by the Nazis. She never held a position at the University of Berlin.

claims.claim: Noether's Theorem states that for every continuous symmetry of a physical system there is a corresponding conservation law
claims.gt_reason: Noether's Theorem (1915/1918), proved by Emmy Noether, states precisely that every differentiable (continuous) symmetry of the action of a physical system corresponds to a conservation law. For example, time-translation symmetry yields conservation of energy, spatial-translation symmetry yields conservation of momentum, and rotational symmetry yields conservation of angular momentum.

claims.claim: Hermann Minkowski was a key figure in the development of special relativity
claims.gt_reason: Hermann Minkowski made foundational contributions to special relativity by developing the geometric framework of spacetime (Minkowski space) in 1907-1908, reformulating Einstein's 1905 theory into a unified 4-dimensional spacetime geometry. His mathematical formulation became essential to the theory and was later adopted by Einstein himself.

claims.claim: Ramanujan was born in 1887
claims.gt_reason: Srinivasa Ramanujan was born on December 22, 1887, in Erode, Tamil Nadu, India.

claims.claim: Ramanujan was born in Erode, Tamil Nadu, India
claims.gt_reason: Srinivasa Ramanujan was born on December 22, 1887, in Erode, Tamil Nadu, India (then part of the Madras Presidency under British rule).

claims.claim: Ramanujan begins formal education in mathematics in 1902
claims.gt_reason: Srinivasa Ramanujan enrolled at Town Higher Secondary School in Kumbakonam in 1898, but it was around 1902–1903 that he first encountered and began seriously engaging with formal mathematics, specifically when he came across S.L. Loney's 'Plane Trigonometry' and similar texts. However, some sources specifically cite 1902 as when he began to excel and pursue mathematics more formally in school. This is a commonly cited date in Ramanujan biographies.

claims.claim: Ramanujan studied under Professor A.P.J. Abdul Kalam at the Madras Presidency College in 1904
claims.gt_reason: A.P.J. Abdul Kalam was born in 1931, decades after Ramanujan attended Madras Presidency College in 1904. Kalam could not have been Ramanujan's professor. Ramanujan's notable academic mentor was G.H. Hardy at Cambridge, not Kalam. Kalam was also primarily known as an aerospace scientist and later President of India, not as a mathematics professor.

claims.claim: Ramanujan studied at the Madras Presidency College
claims.gt_reason: Ramanujan studied at Government Arts College, Kumbakonam, and later at Pachaiyappa's College in Madras — not Madras Presidency College. He failed his exams at both institutions due to neglecting non-mathematical subjects.

claims.claim: Ramanujan encountered G.H. Hardy in 1913
claims.gt_reason: Ramanujan first contacted G.H. Hardy by letter in January 1913, but they did not physically encounter/meet each other until 1914, when Ramanujan traveled to Cambridge. The correspondence began in 1913, but a personal encounter did not occur until the following year.

claims.claim: G.H. Hardy was a mathematician at Cambridge University
claims.gt_reason: G.H. Hardy (1877–1947) was a prominent British mathematician who held positions at Cambridge University, including the Sadleirian Chair of Pure Mathematics, and is renowned for his work in number theory and mathematical analysis, as well as his collaboration with Ramanujan.

claims.claim: Correspondence between Ramanujan and Hardy occurred from 1913 to 1920
claims.gt_reason: parse error

claims.claim: Ramanujan's first paper was titled 'On the Theory of the Continued Fractions of Numbers'
claims.gt_reason: Ramanujan's first published paper was 'Some Properties of Bernoulli's Numbers', published in the Journal of the Indian Mathematical Society in 1911. He did write extensively on continued fractions, but that was not the title or subject of his first paper.

claims.claim: Ramanujan's first paper was published between 1914 and 1916
claims.gt_reason: Ramanujan's first published paper was 'Some Properties of Bernoulli's Numbers,' published in the Journal of the Indian Mathematical Society in 1911, well before 1914.

claims.claim: Hardy published a paper on Ramanujan's work in 1917
claims.gt_reason: While Hardy and Ramanujan collaborated extensively starting in 1914 and published joint papers, I cannot confirm with certainty that Hardy published a paper specifically on Ramanujan's work in 1917 without access to a complete bibliography. Hardy did publish papers in that era, and their famous collaboration on partitions was published in 1918, but I cannot verify a specific 1917 publication without risking a false confirmation.

claims.claim: Ramanujan's Formula for the Partition Function received attention from Hardy in 1916
claims.gt_reason: Hardy and Ramanujan's collaboration on the partition function, which led to their asymptotic formula, was published in 1918, not 1916. Their landmark paper 'Asymptotic Formulae in Combinatory Analysis' appeared in the Proceedings of the London Mathematical Society in 1918.

claims.claim: Ramanujan's Formula relates the number of partitions of a positive integer n to the sum of the reciprocals of its divisors
claims.gt_reason: Ramanujan's work on partitions (developed with Hardy) relates to the asymptotic count of the number of ways to partition an integer n, not to the sum of reciprocals of divisors. The sum of reciprocals of divisors is related to the divisor function σ₋₁(n), which is a separate concept in number theory. The Hardy-Ramanujan asymptotic formula states p(n) ≈ (1/4n√3) · e^(π√(2n/3)).

claims.claim: Rosalind Franklin attended St. Paul's School from 1920 to 1927
claims.gt_reason: Rosalind Franklin attended St. Paul's Girls' School, not St. Paul's School. St. Paul's School is a boys' school; the girls' school is a separate institution. She attended St. Paul's Girls' School from 1932 to 1938, not 1920 to 1927. The dates 1920–1927 are also inconsistent with her birth year of 1920.

claims.claim: St. Paul's School is a girls' boarding school in Hampshire, England
claims.gt_reason: St. Paul's School in Hampshire (Hammersmith, London area) is actually a boys' school. There is a St. Paul's Girls' School, but it is located in London, not Hampshire. Additionally, St. Paul's School (boys) is a day and boarding school in London, not Hampshire.

claims.claim: Rosalind Franklin studied at King's College, London from 1927 to 1934
claims.gt_reason: Rosalind Franklin was born in 1920, so she could not have studied at King's College London from 1927 to 1934 (she would have been 7–14 years old). She actually studied at Newnham College, Cambridge, graduating in 1941. She did work at King's College London as a researcher from 1951 to 1953, but she did not study there as an undergraduate.

claims.claim: Rosalind Franklin graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in Chemistry in 1934
claims.gt_reason: Rosalind Franklin graduated from Newnham College, Cambridge in 1941 (not 1934) with a degree in Natural Sciences, not specifically 'Chemistry'. She was born in 1920, making a 1934 graduation impossible as she would have been only 14 years old.

claims.claim: Rosalind Franklin earned a Master of Science degree in Chemistry from the University of Cambridge from 1934 to 1938
claims.gt_reason: Rosalind Franklin did not earn a Master of Science degree from Cambridge. She attended Newnham College, Cambridge, graduating in 1941 (not 1934–1938) with a degree in Natural Sciences (specializing in chemistry). Cambridge did not award degrees to women until 1948, so she received only a titular BA at the time. She later earned her PhD from Cambridge in 1945 for work done at the British Coal Utilisation Research Association. The dates 1934–1938 are also wrong; she was born in 1920 and would have been only 14–18 during that period.

claims.claim: Rosalind Franklin specialized in crystallography at Cambridge
claims.gt_reason: Rosalind Franklin did her groundbreaking X-ray crystallography work at King's College London (and later Birkbeck College), not Cambridge. She earned her PhD from Cambridge, but her famous crystallography research — including the DNA X-ray diffraction images — was conducted at King's College London.

claims.claim: Rosalind Franklin worked as a research assistant at King's College, London from 1934 to 1938
claims.gt_reason: Rosalind Franklin was born in 1920, so she would have been only 14 years old in 1934, making it impossible for her to have worked as a research assistant at King's College then. She actually joined King's College London in 1951 as a research associate (not assistant) to work on DNA X-ray diffraction, a position she held until 1953.

claims.claim: Rosalind Franklin worked under the supervision of Sir William Lawrence Bragg
claims.gt_reason: Rosalind Franklin worked at King's College London under John Randall, not under William Lawrence Bragg. Bragg was director of the Cavendish Laboratory at Cambridge, where Watson and Crick worked. Franklin's supervisor at King's College was John Randall, who assigned her to work on DNA X-ray crystallography.

claims.claim: Sir William Lawrence Bragg was a renowned X-ray crystallographer
claims.gt_reason: William Lawrence Bragg (1890–1971) was indeed a renowned X-ray crystallographer. He co-developed Bragg's law with his father William Henry Bragg, which describes X-ray diffraction in crystals, and they jointly won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1915 for their work on X-ray crystallography. He remains the youngest Nobel laureate in physics.

claims.claim: Rosalind Franklin joined the King's College, London department of chemistry from 1938 to 1958
claims.gt_reason: Rosalind Franklin was associated with King's College London's Medical Research Council Biophysics Unit (not the chemistry department), and her time there was from 1951 to 1953, not 1938 to 1958. She joined King's College in 1951 and left in 1953 to move to Birkbeck College. The dates 1938–1958 are entirely wrong for her King's College tenure.

claims.claim: Franklin's X-ray crystallography work focused on studying the structure of DNA from 1939 to 1958
claims.gt_reason: Rosalind Franklin's X-ray crystallography work on DNA occurred roughly 1951–1953 at King's College London, not from 1939 to 1958. She died in April 1958, and her earlier career (late 1940s) focused on coal and carbon structures, not DNA. The 1939 start date is wrong — she would have been only 19 and had not yet begun her scientific career in crystallography.

claims.claim: Photo 51 was taken in 1952
claims.gt_reason: Photo 51, the X-ray diffraction image of DNA taken by Rosalind Franklin and Raymond Gosling, was captured in May 1952 at King's College London.

claims.claim: Photo 51 is an X-ray diffraction image of DNA
claims.gt_reason: Photo 51 is an X-ray diffraction image of DNA taken by Rosalind Franklin and Raymond Gosling in 1952, which provided crucial evidence for the double helix structure of DNA.

claims.claim: Photo 51 revealed the helical structure of DNA
claims.gt_reason: Photo 51, an X-ray diffraction image of DNA taken by Rosalind Franklin and Raymond Gosling in 1952, revealed key structural features of DNA including its helical form and the dimensions of the helix. It was crucial evidence used by Watson and Crick in determining the double helix structure of DNA.

claims.claim: Franklin collaborated with Maurice Wilkins at King's College, London
claims.gt_reason: Rosalind Franklin and Maurice Wilkins did not collaborate at King's College London — they had a famously strained and non-collaborative relationship. There was a miscommunication about their roles: Franklin believed she was an independent researcher, while Wilkins thought she was his assistant. They largely worked separately and had significant personal friction. Franklin's X-ray diffraction data (Photo 51) was shared with Watson and Crick without her knowledge or consent, contributing to the discovery of DNA's double helix structure.

claims.claim: Franklin was awarded the Copley Medal in 1958
claims.gt_reason: Rosalind Franklin died on April 16, 1958, and the Copley Medal is awarded by the Royal Society to living scientists. She never received the Copley Medal. Furthermore, the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for the discovery of DNA's structure was awarded in 1962 to Watson, Crick, and Wilkins — after Franklin's death — and Nobel Prizes are not awarded posthumously. Franklin received no such major award.

claims.claim: The Copley Medal is described as the highest honor in the field of science in the UK
claims.gt_reason: The Copley Medal, awarded by the Royal Society, is one of the oldest and most prestigious scientific awards, but it is not typically described as the highest honor in science in the UK. It is awarded for outstanding achievements in research in any branch of science. However, describing it as 'the highest honor in the field of science in the UK' is an overstatement — there is no single universally recognized 'highest' scientific honor in the UK, and the Copley Medal competes in prestige with other honors like Fellowship of the Royal Society or even Nobel Prizes. Some sources do describe it as among the oldest (since 1731) and most prestigious, but 'highest honor in science in the UK' is not the standard characterization.

claims.claim: Galois was born in 1811
claims.gt_reason: Évariste Galois was born on October 25, 1811, in Bourg-la-Reine, France.

claims.claim: Galois was born in the village of Étampes, France
claims.gt_reason: Évariste Galois was born in Bourg-la-Reine, France, not Étampes. Bourg-la-Reine is a commune south of Paris. He was born there on October 25, 1811.

claims.claim: Galois entered the École Polytechnique in 1829
claims.gt_reason: Évariste Galois failed the entrance examination to the École Polytechnique twice, in 1828 and 1829, and was never admitted. He instead enrolled at the École Normale (then called École Préparatoire) in 1829.

claims.claim: The École Polytechnique is a prestigious military academy
claims.gt_reason: École Polytechnique (known as 'l'X') is indeed a prestigious French grande école that operates under the supervision of the French Ministry of Armed Forces and holds military status. Students are military officers in training and receive military pay during their studies.

claims.claim: Galois graduated from the École Polytechnique in 1831
claims.gt_reason: Évariste Galois never graduated from the École Polytechnique. He failed the entrance examination twice (in 1827 and 1829) and was never admitted. He instead attended the École Normale Supérieure, from which he was expelled in 1831. He died in a duel in 1832 at age 20.

claims.claim: Galois graduated at the age of 20
claims.gt_reason: Évariste Galois did not graduate in the traditional sense — he was famously rejected twice by the École Polytechnique. He was admitted to the École Normale in 1829 at age 17, but was expelled in 1830 at age 18/19. He died at age 20 in a duel in 1832, never having completed a formal degree or graduation.

claims.claim: Galois graduated with honors
claims.gt_reason: Évariste Galois did not graduate with honors. He twice failed the entrance examination to the École Polytechnique and was eventually admitted to the lesser École Normale. He was later expelled from the École Normale in 1831. His academic career was marked by failures and rejection, not honors.

claims.claim: Galois published papers on theory of equations and group theory during 1832-1834
claims.gt_reason: Évariste Galois died on May 31, 1832, from wounds sustained in a duel. He could not have published papers during 1832-1834. His work on the theory of equations and group theory was written before his death (notably the night before his duel) and was only published posthumously, primarily through the efforts of Joseph Liouville, who published Galois's manuscripts in 1846.

claims.claim: Galois earned his doctorate from the University of Paris in 1834
claims.gt_reason: Évariste Galois never earned a doctorate. He died on May 31, 1832, at age 20, from wounds sustained in a duel. He was repeatedly rejected by the École Polytechnique and had a turbulent academic career, but never completed a doctorate. His mathematical work on what became Galois theory was only recognized and published posthumously.

claims.claim: Galois earned his doctorate at the age of 23
claims.gt_reason: Évariste Galois died at age 20 (born 1811, died 1832) and never earned a doctorate. He was twice rejected by the École Polytechnique and his mathematical manuscripts were largely unrecognized during his lifetime. He could not have earned a doctorate at 23.

claims.claim: Galois penned a final letter titled 'Letter to the Minister of War' in June 1835
claims.gt_reason: Galois did write a famous final letter the night before his duel, but it was addressed to his friend Auguste Chevalier, not to the Minister of War. The letter was written on May 29, 1832 (the night before his fatal duel on May 30, 1832), not in June 1835. Galois died on May 31, 1832 from wounds sustained in the duel.

claims.claim: Galois died on June 30th
claims.gt_reason: Évariste Galois died on May 31, 1832, not June 30th. He was wounded in a duel on May 30 and died the following morning.

claims.claim: Galois died in 1835
claims.gt_reason: Évariste Galois died on May 31, 1832, from wounds sustained in a duel the previous day, not 1835.

claims.claim: Galois died at the age of 25
claims.gt_reason: Évariste Galois was born on October 25, 1811, and died on May 31, 1832, from wounds sustained in a duel. He was 20 years old at the time of his death, not 25.

claims.claim: Galois died in Lyon, France
claims.gt_reason: Évariste Galois died in Paris, France (specifically at the Cochin Hospital), not in Lyon. He died on May 31, 1832, from wounds sustained in a duel fought the previous day near the Gentilly pond on the outskirts of Paris.

claims.claim: Galois died at the hands of a group of soldiers
claims.gt_reason: Évariste Galois died on May 31, 1832, from wounds sustained in a duel with a single opponent (likely Perscheux d'Herbinville), not at the hands of a group of soldiers.
